* Google CEO calls for balanced approach to data regulations * CEO Pichai supports multilateral solution on digital taxes By Aditya Kalra NEW DELHI, July 13 (Reuters) – Alphabet Inc’s Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that... * Google CEO calls for balanced approach to data...

* Google CEO calls for balanced approach to data regulations * CEO Pichai supports multilateral solution on digital taxes By Aditya Kalra NEW DELHI, July 13 (Reuters) – Alphabet Inc’s Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that...

* Google CEO calls for balanced approach to data regulations * CEO Pichai supports multilateral solution on digital taxes By Aditya Kalra NEW DELHI, July 13 (Reuters) – Alphabet Inc’s Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chief executive Sundar Pichai told Reuters in an interview. The OECD talks involve over 100 countries on a major rewrite of global tax rules to bring them up to date for the digital era, but they have so far not produced results as the negotiations have been complicated by the coronavirus pandemic. The United States has already initiated investigations of digital services taxes adopted or being considered by countries such as France, India and Turkey, saying it discriminates against U.S. tech firms. Pichai said it was important to rely on OECD frameworks, which he referred to as the “right approach”. “It’s not (an issue) for an individual company to solve,” Pichai said in an interview from San Francisco via a video conference. “We would be supportive of the OECD engagement.” Countries imposing digital service taxes see it as a way to raise revenue from the local operations of big tech companies which they say profit enormously from local markets while making only limited contributions to public coffers. Google and other companies have been concerned with India’s recent decision to impose a 2% digital tax that also applies on advertising revenue earned overseas if the ads target customers in India, Reuters has previously reported. Pichai did not directly comment on the Indian tax. His comments came as Google announced a plan on Monday to invest $10 billion into Indian companies over 5-7 years, marking its biggest bet on the South Asian market and its fast-growing digital economy. Google and other tech companies also continue to face a raft of regulatory hurdles around the world as governments impose more controls over how big technology companies use and process data of millions of users. In terms of the data regulations being developed in India and other countries, Pichai called for a balanced approach of policy making that promotes innovation. “It’s important you find the balance in protecting the privacy of your citizens but allowing for free flow of products and services,” Pichai said. “That’s the potential of a digital economy … the strength of the internet comes in the fact that it works globally.” Data storage rules, for example, have been criticised for hindering long-term growth of companies, while restrictions on cross-border data flows has been blamed for hampering innovation. Governments, however, say such controls are necessary for protecting user privacy and data abuse. (Reporting by Aditya Kalra. Editing by Jane Merriman)

NEW DELHI (Reuters) - Alphabet Inc’s ( GOOGL.O ) Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chief executive Sundar Pichai told Reuters in an interview. FILE PHOTO: Sundar Pichai, Chief Executive Officer of Alphabet, looks on during a session of the 50th World Economic Forum (WEF) annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, January 22, 2020. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse The OECD talks involve over 100 countries on a major rewrite of global tax rules to bring them up to date for the digital era, but they have so far not produced results as the negotiations have been complicated by the coronavirus pandemic. By NEW DELHI (Reuters) - Alphabet Inc's Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chief executive Sundar Pichai told Reuters in an i...

By NEW DELHI (Reuters) - Alphabet Inc's Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chief executive Sundar Pichai told Reuters in an interview. The OECD talks involve over 100 countries on a major rewrite of global tax rules to bring them up to date for the digital era, but they have so far not produced results as the negotiations have been complicated by the coronavirus pandemic. The United States has already initiated investigations of digital services taxes adopted or being considered by countries such as France, India and Turkey, saying it discriminates against U.S. tech firms. "It's not (an issue) for an individual company to solve," Pichai said in an interview from San Francisco via a video conference. "We would be supportive of the OECD engagement." Countries imposing digital service taxes see it as a way to raise revenue from the local operations of big tech companies which they say profit enormously from local markets while making only limited contributions to public coffers. Google and other companies have been concerned with India's recent decision to impose a 2% digital tax that also applies on advertising revenue earned overseas if the ads target customers in India, Reuters has previously reported. Pichai did not directly comment on the Indian tax. His comments came as Google announced a plan on Monday to invest $10 billion into Indian companies over 5-7 years, marking its biggest bet on the South Asian market and its fast-growing digital economy. Google and other tech companies also continue to face a raft of regulatory hurdles around the world as governments impose more controls over how big technology companies use and process data of millions of users. In terms of the data regulations being developed in India and other countries, Pichai called for a balanced approach of policy making that promotes innovation. "It's important you find the balance in protecting the privacy of your citizens but allowing for free flow of products and services," Pichai said. "That's the potential of a digital economy ... the strength of the internet comes in the fact that it works globally." Data storage rules, for example, have been criticised for hindering long-term growth of companies, while restrictions on cross-border data flows has been blamed for hampering innovation. Governments, however, say such controls are necessary for protecting user privacy and data abuse. (Reporting by Aditya Kalra. Editing by Jane Merriman)

NEW DELHI: Alphabet Inc's Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chief executive Sundar Pichai said in an interview. The OECD tal...

NEW DELHI: Alphabet Inc's Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chief executive Sundar Pichai said in an interview. The OECD talks involve over 100 countries on a major rewrite of global tax rules to bring them up to date for the digital era, but they have so far not produced results as the negotiations have been complicated by the coronavirus pandemic. The United States has already initiated investigations of digital services taxes adopted or being considered by countries such as France, India and Turkey, saying it discriminates against US tech firms. Pichai said it was important to rely on OECD frameworks, which he referred to as the "right approach". "It's not (an issue) for an individual company to solve," Pichai said in an interview from San Francisco via a video conference. "We would be supportive of the OECD engagement." Countries imposing digital service taxes see it as a way to raise revenue from the local operations of big tech companies which they say profit enormously from local markets while making only limited contributions to public coffers. Google and other companies have been concerned with India's recent decision to impose a 2% digital tax that also applies on advertising revenue earned overseas if the ads target customers in India, Reuters has previously reported. Pichai did not directly comment on the Indian tax. His comments came as Google announced a plan on July 13 to invest US$10bil (RM42.65bil) into Indian companies over 5-7 years, marking its biggest bet on the South Asian market and its fast-growing digital economy. Google and other tech companies also continue to face a raft of regulatory hurdles around the world as governments impose more controls over how big technology companies use and process data of millions of users. In terms of the data regulations being developed in India and other countries, Pichai called for a balanced approach of policy making that promotes innovation. "It's important you find the balance in protecting the privacy of your citizens but allowing for free flow of products and services," Pichai said. "That's the potential of a digital economy... the strength of the Internet comes in the fact that it works globally." Data storage rules, for example, have been criticised for hindering long-term growth of companies, while restrictions on cross-border data flows has been blamed for hampering innovation. Governments, however, say such controls are necessary for protecting user privacy and data abuse. – Reuters

value.Title: Google supports OECD engagement on digital taxes, CEO Pichai says
value.Overview: Bruegel think tank conference in Brussels More By NEW DELHI (Reuters) - Alphabet Inc's Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chi... Bruegel think tank conference in Brussels More By NEW...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60BN-Y6M1-JCSC-J50P-00000-00Google supports OECD engagement on digital taxes, CEO Pichai says2020-07-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisNEWSGoogle supports OECD engagement on digital taxes, CEO Pichai saysAditya Kalra

Bruegel think tank conference in Brussels More By NEW DELHI (Reuters) - Alphabet Inc's Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chi... Bruegel think tank conference in Brussels More By NEW...

Bruegel think tank conference in Brussels More By NEW DELHI (Reuters) - Alphabet Inc's Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chi...

Bruegel think tank conference in Brussels More By NEW DELHI (Reuters) - Alphabet Inc's Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chief executive Sundar Pichai told Reuters in an interview. The OECD talks involve over 100 countries on a major rewrite of global tax rules to bring them up to date for the digital era, but they have so far not produced results as the negotiations have been complicated by the coronavirus pandemic. The United States has already initiated investigations of digital services taxes adopted or being considered by countries such as France, India and Turkey, saying it discriminates against U.S. tech firms. Pichai said it was important to rely on OECD frameworks, which he referred to as the "right approach". "It's not (an issue) for an individual company to solve," Pichai said in an interview from San Francisco via a video conference. "We would be supportive of the OECD engagement." Countries imposing digital service taxes see it as a way to raise revenue from the local operations of big tech companies which they say profit enormously from local markets while making only limited contributions to public coffers. Google and other companies have been concerned with India's recent decision to impose a 2% digital tax that also applies on advertising revenue earned overseas if the ads target customers in India, Reuters has previously reported. Pichai did not directly comment on the Indian tax. His comments came as Google announced a plan on Monday to invest $10 billion into Indian companies over 5-7 years, marking its biggest bet on the South Asian market and its fast-growing digital economy. Google and other tech companies also continue to face a raft of regulatory hurdles around the world as governments impose more controls over how big technology companies use and process data of millions of users. In terms of the data regulations being developed in India and other countries, Pichai called for a balanced approach of policy making that promotes innovation. "It's important you find the balance in protecting the privacy of your citizens but allowing for free flow of products and services," Pichai said. "That's the potential of a digital economy ... the strength of the internet comes in the fact that it works globally." Data storage rules, for example, have been criticised for hindering long-term growth of companies, while restrictions on cross-border data flows has been blamed for hampering innovation. Governments, however, say such controls are necessary for protecting user privacy and data abuse. (Reporting by Aditya Kalra. Editing by Jane Merriman)

NEW DELHI (Reuters) - Alphabet Inc’s ( GOOGL.O ) Google supports a multilateral solution for taxing digital services that is under discussion by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), its chief executive Sundar Pichai told Reuters in an interview. The OECD talks involve over 100 countries on a major rewrite of global tax rules to bring them up to date for the digital era, but they have so far not produced results as the negotiations have been complicated by the coronavirus pandemic. Pichai said it was important to rely on OECD frameworks, which he referred to as the “right approach”. “It’s not (an issue) for an individual company to solve,” Pichai said in an interview from San Francisco via a video conference. “We would be supportive of the OECD engagement.” Countries imposing digital service taxes see it as a way to raise revenue from the local operations of big tech companies which they say profit enormously from local markets while making only limited contributions to public coffers. Google and other companies have been concerned with India’s recent decision to impose a 2% digital tax that also applies on advertising revenue earned overseas if the ads target customers in India, Reuters has previously reported. Pichai did not directly comment on the Indian tax. His comments came as Google announced a plan on Monday to invest $10 billion into Indian companies over 5-7 years, marking its biggest bet on the South Asian market and its fast-growing digital economy. Google and other tech companies also continue to face a raft of regulatory hurdles around the world as governments impose more controls over how big technology companies use and process data of millions of users. In terms of the data regulations being developed in India and other countries, Pichai called for a balanced approach of policy making that promotes innovation. “It’s important you find the balance in protecting the privacy of your citizens but allowing for free flow of products and services,” Pichai said. “That’s the potential of a digital economy ... the strength of the internet comes in the fact that it works globally.” Data storage rules, for example, have been criticised for hindering long-term growth of companies, while restrictions on cross-border data flows has been blamed for hampering innovation. Governments, however, say such controls are necessary for protecting user privacy and data abuse.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60YX-63D1-JC42-D2FY-00000-00Google's US$1B fund to pay global media for news content2020-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A5Google's US$1B fund to pay global media for news contentBarbara ShecterFinancial PostToronto

TORONTO Google Inc. has set aside US$1 billion to pay global publishers for news content over the next three years, but, when it comes to Canada, only two small digital-only media players are part of the licensing arrangement so far.

Narcity, which targets millennials, and Village Media, a local news operation in Ontario, are among the 200 publishers in Canada, the United Kingdom, Germany, Australia, Brazil and Argentina that have signed up to Google's News Showcase program, where the media outlets will be paid for blurbs of news items displayed on the search platform. The search giant will also pay to give readers access to selected articles that are behind a pay wall.

It is understood that Google is approaching publishers individually, so larger media outlets in Canada, such as Torstar Corp., owner of the Toronto Star, and National Post owner Postmedia Inc., are likely to be approached, said John Hinds, chief executive of the industry group News Media Canada. Less clear is whether they will be in favour of the terms the tech giant is offering.

"With the announcement of $1 billion globally there won't be a lot of money for Canada," said Hinds.

He estimated that about $9 million would be earmarked for Canada based on per capita spend.

That amount is just a fraction of what some countries believe the tech giants should be paying media. In Australia, for example, legislation is being developed with the expectation that news organizations in that country alone might receive between $600 million and $1 billion Google and Facebook Inc.

Hinds noted that the recent throne speech delivered in Ottawa suggests the Canadian government, too, is considering putting a framework in place that would require the digital giants to pay for content.

Traditional media outlets have complained for years that they aren't compensated by large digital platforms such as Google and Facebook, which showcase news items to attract audiences and generate revenue from search and user data.

Governments and regulators around the world, particularly in Europe and Australia, have begun to look at the market power of the big tech firms, and are putting measures in place to help level the playing field.

But the tech giants have pushed back, suggesting that linking to third-party news sites generates little income for their platforms. In response to a mandatory code of conduct being passed into law in Australia, Facebook indicated last month that it could stop the sharing of news items on its platform there altogether. In the past, Google has pulled its Google News aggregation site from users in countries where reform measures were considered out of line.

Michael Geist, a law professor at the University of Ottawa and Canada Research Chair in internet and e-commerce law, said uncertainty in Canada over what the government plans to do to level the playing field - and when - could encourage publishers to skip licensing their content at market rates with Google. Instead, they could hold out "in the hope that the Canadian government will mandate payments well above market value," he said.

But Jeff Elgie, chief executive of Village Media, said joining Google's News Showcase licensing arrangement was an "easy decision" for the Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.-based company.

"This is a new and meaningful revenue stream for us," he said, adding that it fulfils an important goal by keeping the "user experience" on Village Media's website while attracting traffic and hopefully new audiences from Google.

"And in this case, we're being paid for it," he said. Financial Post !@COPYRIGHT=© 2020 Osprey Media Group Inc. All rights reserved.

urn:contentItem:60YX-BJG1-JBKR-1368-00000-00Google's US$1B fund to pay global media for news content; Two small publishers in Canada among 200 around world that have signed up2020-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. Google Inc. has set aside US$1 billion to pay global publishers for news content over the next three years, but, when it comes to Canada, only two small digital-only media players are part of the licensing arrangement so far.

Narcity, which targets millennials, and Village Media, a local news operation in Ontario, are among the 200 publishers in Canada, the United Kingdom, Germany, Australia, Brazil and Argentina that have signed up to Google's News Showcase program, where the media outlets will be paid for blurbs of news items displayed on the search platform. The search giant will also pay to give readers access to selected articles that are behind a pay wall.

It is understood that Google is approaching publishers individually, so larger media outlets in Canada, such as Torstar Corp., owner of the Toronto Star, and National Post owner Postmedia Inc., are likely to be approached, said John Hinds, chief executive of the industry group News Media Canada. Less clear is whether they will be in favour of the terms the tech giant is offering.

"With the announcement of $1 billion globally there won't be a lot of money for Canada," said Hinds.

He estimated that about $9 million would be earmarked for Canada based on per capita spend.

That amount is just a fraction of what some countries believe the tech giants should be paying media. In Australia, for example, legislation is being developed with the expectation that news organizations in that country alone might receive between $600 million and $1 billion from Google and Facebook Inc.

Hinds noted that the recent throne speech delivered in Ottawa suggests the Canadian government, too, is considering putting a framework in place that would require the digital giants to pay for content.

Traditional media outlets have complained for years that they aren't compensated by large digital platforms such as Google and Facebook, which showcase news items to attract audiences and generate revenue from search and user data.

Governments and regulators around the world, particularly in Europe and Australia, have begun to look at the market power of the big tech firms, and are putting measures in place to help level the playing field.

But the tech giants have pushed back, suggesting that linking to third-party news sites generates little income for their platforms. In response to a mandatory code of conduct being passed into law in Australia, Facebook indicated last month that it could stop the sharing of news items on its platform there altogether. In the past, Google has pulled its Google News aggregation site from users in countries where reform measures were considered out of line.

Michael Geist, a law professor at the University of Ottawa and Canada Research Chair in internet and e-commerce law, said uncertainty in Canada over what the government plans to do to level the playing field - and when - could encourage publishers to skip licensing their content at market rates with Google. Instead, they could hold out "in the hope that the Canadian government will mandate payments well above market value," he said.

But Jeff Elgie, chief executive of Village Media, said joining Google's News Showcase licensing arrangement was an "easy decision" for the Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.-based company.

"This is a new and meaningful revenue stream for us," he said, adding that it fulfils an important goal by keeping the "user experience" on Village Media's website while attracting traffic and hopefully new audiences from Google.

"And in this case, we're being paid for it," he said. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2020 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

Krisztian Bocsi, Bloomberg Files; Industry group News Media Canada thinks Google's fund for news content would not be enough for Canada if it were earmarked at about $9 million.;

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60YX-6FF1-DY2S-V145-00000-00Google's US$1B fund to pay global media for news content; Two small publishers in Canada among 200 around world that have signed up2020-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:27ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. NP5Google's US$1B fund to pay global media for news content; Two small publishers in Canada among 200 around world that have signed upBarbara ShecterFinancial PostToronto

Google Inc. has set aside to pay global publishers for news content over the next three years, but, when it comes to Canada, only two small digital-only media players are part of the licensing arrangement so far.

Narcity, which targets millennials, and Village Media, a local news operation in Ontario, are among the 200 publishers in Canada, the United Kingdom, Germany, Australia, Brazil and Argentina that have signed up to Google's News Showcase program, where the media outlets will be paid for blurbs of news items displayed on the search platform. The search giant will also pay to give readers access to selected articles that are behind a pay wall.

It is understood that Google is approaching publishers individually, so larger media outlets in Canada, such as Torstar Corp., owner of the Toronto Star, and National Post owner Postmedia Inc., are likely to be approached, said John Hinds, chief executive of the industry group News Media Canada. Less clear is whether they will be in favour of the terms the tech giant is offering.

"With the announcement of $1 billion globally there won't be a lot of money for Canada," said Hinds.

He estimated that about $9 million would be earmarked for Canada based on per capita spend.

That amount is just a fraction of what some countries believe the tech giants should be paying media. In Australia, for example, legislation is being developed with the expectation that news organizations in that country alone might receive between $600 million and $1 billion from Google and Facebook Inc.

Hinds noted that the recent throne speech delivered in Ottawa suggests the Canadian government, too, is considering putting a framework in place that would require the digital giants to pay for content.

Traditional media outlets have complained for years that they aren't compensated by large digital platforms such as Google and Facebook, which showcase news items to attract audiences and generate revenue from search and user data.

Governments and regulators around the world, particularly in Europe and Australia, have begun to look at the market power of the big tech firms, and are putting measures in place to help level the playing field.

But the tech giants have pushed back, suggesting that linking to third-party news sites generates little income for their platforms. In response to a mandatory code of conduct being passed into law in Australia, Facebook indicated last month that it could stop the sharing of news items on its platform there altogether. In the past, Google has pulled its Google News aggregation site from users in countries where reform measures were considered out of line.

Michael Geist, a law professor at the University of Ottawa and Canada Research Chair in internet and e-commerce law, said uncertainty in Canada over what the government plans to do to level the playing field - and when - could encourage publishers to skip licensing their content at market rates with Google. Instead, they could hold out "in the hope that the Canadian government will mandate payments well above market value," he said.

But Jeff Elgie, chief executive of Village Media, said joining Google's News Showcase licensing arrangement was an "easy decision" for the Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.-based company.

"This is a new and meaningful revenue stream for us," he said, adding that it fulfils an important goal by keeping the "user experience" on Village Media's website while attracting traffic and hopefully new audiences from Google.

"And in this case, we're being paid for it," he said. Financial Post !@COPYRIGHT=© 2020 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

Krisztian Bocsi, Bloomberg Files; Industry group News Media Canada thinks Google's fund for news content would not be enough for Canada if it were earmarked at about $9 million.;

urn:contentItem:60YX-BJH1-JBKR-R3JB-00000-00Google's US$1B fund to pay global media for news content; Two small publishers in Canada among 200 around world that have signed up2020-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. A6Google's US$1B fund to pay global media for news content; Two small publishers in Canada among 200 around world that have signed upBarbara ShecterFinancial PostToronto

Google Inc. has set aside US$1 billion to pay global publishers for news content over the next three years, but, when it comes to Canada, only two small digital-only media players are part of the licensing arrangement so far.

Narcity, which targets millennials, and Village Media, a local news operation in Ontario, are among the 200 publishers in Canada, the United Kingdom, Germany, Australia, Brazil and Argentina that have signed up to Google's News Showcase program, where the media outlets will be paid for blurbs of news items displayed on the search platform. The search giant will also pay to give readers access to selected articles that are behind a pay wall.

It is understood that Google is approaching publishers individually, so larger media outlets in Canada, such as Torstar Corp., owner of the Toronto Star, and National Post owner Postmedia Inc., are likely to be approached, said John Hinds, chief executive of the industry group News Media Canada. Less clear is whether they will be in favour of the terms the tech giant is offering.

"With the announcement of $1 billion globally there won't be a lot of money for Canada," said Hinds.

He estimated that about $9 million would be earmarked for Canada based on per capita spend.

That amount is just a fraction of what some countries believe the tech giants should be paying media. In Australia, for example, legislation is being developed with the expectation that news organizations in that country alone might receive between $600 million and $1 billion Google and Facebook Inc.

Hinds noted that the recent throne speech delivered in Ottawa suggests the Canadian government, too, is considering putting a framework in place that would require the digital giants to pay for content.

Traditional media outlets have complained for years that they aren't compensated by large digital platforms such as Google and Facebook, which showcase news items to attract audiences and generate revenue from search and user data.

Governments and regulators around the world, particularly in Europe and Australia, have begun to look at the market power of the big tech firms, and are putting measures in place to help level the playing field.

But the tech giants have pushed back, suggesting that linking to third-party news sites generates little income for their platforms. In response to a mandatory code of conduct being passed into law in Australia, Facebook indicated last month that it could stop the sharing of news items on its platform there altogether. In the past, Google has pulled its Google News aggregation site from users in countries where reform measures were considered out of line.

Michael Geist, a law professor at the University of Ottawa and Canada Research Chair in internet and e-commerce law, said uncertainty in Canada over what the government plans to do to level the playing field - and when - could encourage publishers to skip licensing their content at market rates with Google. Instead, they could hold out "in the hope that the Canadian government will mandate payments well above market value," he said.

But Jeff Elgie, chief executive of Village Media, said joining Google's News Showcase licensing arrangement was an "easy decision" for the Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.-based company.

"This is a new and meaningful revenue stream for us," he said, adding that it fulfils an important goal by keeping the "user experience" on Village Media's website while attracting traffic and hopefully new audiences from Google.

"And in this case, we're being paid for it," he said. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2020 Sun Media Corporation. All rights reserved.

Krisztian Bocsi, Bloomberg Files; Industry group News Media Canada thinks Google's fund for news content would not be enough for Canada if it were earmarked at about $9 million.;

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60R9-FV71-DY0W-42RJ-00000-00Google's warning against the Federalist is why libertarians will lose fight over Big Tech2020-06-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisOPINIONGoogle's warning against the Federalist is why libertarians will lose fight over Big TechPhilip KleinWashington, D.C.FULL TEXT

When it comes to the regulation of private businesses, I consider myself a libertarian. But as a realist, I recognize that when businesses become big and begin to be seen as abusing their power, they make it much harder for defenders of a pure free market to prevail in the regulatory debate.

NBC's attempt to deplatform the Federalist was only made possible by the immense power that Google has, with a near monopoly on the search traffic that fuels its advertising business. While it turns out that NBC got the story wrong, Google did put the Federalist on notice that it could lose access to Google Ads revenue if it didn't change its comment section, which has been temporarily removed.

In the debate concerning whether to target tech companies over their bias against conservatives, I've been on the side of arguing that private businesses should have the right to set any rules they want for users. I was critical of a proposal by Sen. Josh Hawley that would have ended the immunity that social media companies have against lawsuits for content posted on their platforms. Under his proposal, companies would have to apply to the federal government for temporary certificates of immunity after demonstrating they've been free of political bias in removing content. On the left, Sen. Elizabeth Warren has proposed breaking up large tech companies — though for different reasons.

Arguments in favor of the free market are always weakened when businesses behave in ways that make it easy for people to portray them as the bad guys.

A free market healthcare system has been made harder to achieve by stories of insurers fighting to deny care to those who have insurance, of hospitals issuing exorbitant bills that are hard to justify, and of drug companies that rely on patent protection to charge jaw-dropping amounts for prescription drugs. Manufacturers that recklessly polluted and then tried to cover it up made it more difficult to argue against environmental regulations, and big banks that blew up the economy and then demanded bailouts made it more difficult to make the case against financial regulation.

Google, in trying to explain its threat against the Federalist, stated, "Our policies do not allow ads to run against dangerous or derogatory content, which includes comments on sites." To which many people had the same reaction: Has Google not looked at the comments section of any typical video on its own YouTube service?

This was not lost on Hawley.

Tweet

On Wednesday, he is introducing legislation that would give "users the right to sue if the big platforms enforce their terms unfairly or unequally." He is being joined by Sens. Marco Rubio, Tom Cotton, and Mike Braun.

In a political world in which most people are more interested in outcomes rather than underlying principles, if the power of Google and other large tech companies is used to disproportionately target conservatives, it's going to be increasingly difficult for those on the libertarian side of the spectrum to win any argument over the freedom of these companies to self-police.

Photo Caption:Kyiv, Ukraine - March 13, 2011: Google logo in browser window on monitor screen. In main window are links to other Google products, as Gmail and other. Google is the most powerful search engine now.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VP2-3MT1-JCMN-Y218-00000-00Google's weird name and logo for its new gaming service is part of a clever disappearing act (GOOG, GOOGL)2019-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:27ZLexisNexisGoogle's weird name and logo for its new gaming service is part of a clever disappearing act (GOOG, GOOGL)Alexei Oreskovic

Mar 20, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Google's[1] new game streaming service is called Stadia[2]. It's an apt name with a pretty logo, but it's missing something. Looking at the Stadia logo, you'd never know it was part of Google — and there's a good reason for that. Google took the wraps off its game streaming service on Tuesday [3]with a barrage of fanfare, high-octane demos and a shiny new name and logo. Meet: Stadia.

As far as names go, it's not bad. According to the Cambridge Dictionary,[4] Stadia is a plural form of stadiums — an apt moniker for a product that aspires to provide virtual arenas for gamers and spectators anywhere in the world. "One place... where you, and everyone you know, and everyone they know, will all play together," the narrator of Stadia's introductory video[5] explains in a solemn tone. For me though, the most striking thing about the new name and logo, is how utterly foreign it is to the Google brand. And that's not an accident. Stadia's giant S looks like it belongs on the chest of a cartoon superhero. There's no mention of its Google pedigree anywhere (other than a brief flash of the letter G at the end of the demo video). And the visual cues (such as the standard color palette) that Google typically uses to tie together its family of products are notably absent. Take a look at the logos below. All are Google products, but one of them is not like the others.Google Fi, the company's wireless phone service: Google Photos:Google Maps:And here's Stadia: Sure, not all Google products mention Google. YouTube, which Google acquired for $1.65 billion back in 2006, has preserved its identity as an independent brand.Unlike YouTube, however, Stadia doesn't have a pre-existing brand to preserve. The Google foundation that Stadia is built on is one of its greatest assets. Google's vast network of data centers and undersea cables will make the games Stadia streams rock solid and lag-free; Google's AI prowess will enhance the gaming experience with integrated features like Google Assistant; Sundar Pichai, Google's CEO, even spoke at the event, underscoring the importance of the relationship. So Stadia's conscious decoupling with Google in its brand identity is worth paying attention to. We've seen Google do this before. When Google introduced its mobile operating system a decade ago, it wanted the phone industry to embrace it as the answer to the rising iPhone threat. But even though phone companies were worried about Apple eating their lunch, there was distrust of Google too. Enter Android, a cute little green alien that looks nothing like the rest of Google's brands:Now, as Google barges into another established market, the company is walking a similar tightrope. Google's success in gaming will in large part come down to winning the support of industry incumbents — the game developers and studios that it hopes to offer on its streaming platform. There's reason for them to be wary. After all, they'll be giving up control over distribution, customer relationships and perhaps even a portion of their revenue to Google. The precedents for these kinds of arrangements, whether in music or publishing, are not feel-good stories. Google might even one day pose a serious threat to the largest game makers. Stadia Games and Entertainment, the first-party studio that was also announced on Tuesday, is tasked with creating games specifically for the Stadia streaming platform[6]. The story right now is that this will let Google work hand-in-hand with independent game studios to develop experiences that sizzle on the streaming service. But as Google also builds its own games, it runs the risk of building up into the kind of heavyweight that draws audience away from the established players. That's precisely the kind of arrangement that regulators and politicians are increasingly criticizing. A major pillar of US Presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren's rationale for breaking up big tech companies[7] is that Google and Apple run marketplaces for apps and other services, while also promoting their own products in those marketplaces. Will Google try to do the same thing with Stadia? It's too early to know. Right now, Google isn't even revealing the price of the service, which is due to launch sometime later this year. Until then, the world must wait and marvel at the beauty of Stadia's gleaming S logo. Read more: Google just unveiled its vision for 'the future of gaming' — here's everything it announced[8] Google's new Stadia gaming service supports so many devices you might not need to buy anything[9] Industry veteran Jade Raymond is in charge of turning Google into a major video game publisher — and that has huge ramifications[10] Google just unveiled Stadia, its ambitious attempt to upend the video-game industry and take on Xbox and PlayStation. Here's everything we know.[11] NOW WATCH: We tried Louis Vuitton's wireless earbuds to find out if they're worth the $995[12]See Also: I tried Stadia, Google's big play to conquer video games. It's really promising, but there's still too much we don't know.[13]Google just unveiled Stadia, its ambitious attempt to upend the video-game industry and take on Xbox and PlayStation. Here's everything we know.[14]Google just unveiled its Netflix-like video-game platform Stadia[15] [ 1]: Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VP1-Y3F1-DXY7-W14F-00000-00Google's weird name and logo for its new gaming service is part of a clever disappearing act (GOOG, GOOGL)2019-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisGoogle's weird name and logo for its new gaming service is part of a clever disappearing act (GOOG, GOOGL)aoreskovic@businessinsider.com (Alexei Oreskovic)

Looking at the Stadia logo, you'd never know it was part of Google - and there's a good reason for that.

REUTERS/Stephen Lam

Google's new game streaming service is called   Stadia.

It's an apt name with a pretty logo, but it's missing something. 

Looking at the Stadia logo, you'd never know it was part of Google - and there's a good reason for that.

Google took the wraps off its game streaming service on Tuesday with a barrage of fanfare, high-octane demos and a shiny new name and logo.

Meet: Stadia.

As far as names go, it's not bad. According to the Cambridge Dictionary, Stadia is a plural form of stadiums - an apt moniker for a product that aspires to provide virtual arenas for gamers and spectators anywhere in the world. 

"One place... where you, and everyone you know, and everyone they know, will all play together," the narrator of Stadia's introductory video explains in a solemn tone.

For me though, the most striking thing about the new name and logo, is how utterly foreign it is to the Google brand. And that's not an accident. 

Stadia's giant S looks like it belongs on the chest of a cartoon superhero. There's no mention of its Google pedigree anywhere (other than a brief flash of the letter G at the end of the demo video). And the visual cues (such as the standard color palette) that Google typically uses to tie together its family of products are notably absent.

Take a look at the logos below. All are Google products, but one of them is not like the others. 

Google Fi, the company's wireless phone service:

Google

 

Google Photos:

Google

Google Maps:

Google

And here's Stadia:

Google

Sure, not all Google products mention Google. YouTube, which Google acquired for $1.65 billion back in 2006, has preserved its identity as an independent brand. 

Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg via Getty Images

Unlike YouTube, however, Stadia doesn't have a pre-existing brand to preserve.

The Google foundation that Stadia is built on is one of its greatest assets. Google's vast network of data centers and undersea cables will make the games Stadia streams rock solid and lag-free; Google's AI prowess will enhance the gaming experience with integrated features like Google Assistant; Sundar Pichai, Google's CEO, even spoke at the event, underscoring the importance of the relationship.

So Stadia's conscious decoupling with Google in its brand identity is worth paying attention to. 

We've seen Google do this before. When Google introduced its mobile operating system a decade ago, it wanted the phone industry to embrace it as the answer to the rising iPhone threat. But even though phone companies were worried about Apple eating their lunch, there was distrust of Google too.

Enter Android, a cute little green alien that looks nothing like the rest of Google's brands:

Android Instagram page

Now, as Google barges into another established market, the company is walking a similar tightrope. Google's success in gaming will in large part come down to winning the support of industry incumbents - the game developers and studios that it hopes to offer on its streaming platform. 

There's reason for them to be wary. After all, they'll be giving up control over distribution, customer relationships and perhaps even a portion of their revenue to Google. The precedents for these kinds of arrangements, whether in music or publishing, are not feel-good stories.

Google might even one day pose a serious threat to the largest game makers. Stadia Games and Entertainment, the first-party studio that was also announced on Tuesday, is tasked with creating games specifically for the Stadia streaming platform. The story right now is that this will let Google work hand-in-hand with independent game studios to develop experiences that sizzle on the streaming service. But as Google also builds its own games, it runs the risk of building up into the kind of heavyweight that draws audience away from the established players.

That's precisely the kind of arrangement that regulators and politicians are increasingly criticizing. A major pillar of US Presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren's rationale for breaking up big tech companies is that Google and Apple run marketplaces for apps and other services, while also promoting their own products in those marketplaces.

You can't have both, in Warren's view, especially if you're a giant tech comapny like Google.

Will Google try to use its size and advantages the same way with Stadia? It's too early to know. Right now, Google isn't even revealing the price of the service, which is due to launch sometime later this year. 

Until then, the world can only wait and marvel at the beauty of Stadia's gleaming S logo.

Read more:

Google just unveiled its vision for 'the future of gaming' - here's everything it announced

Google's new Stadia gaming service supports so many devices you might not need to buy anything

Industry veteran Jade Raymond is in charge of turning Google into a major video game publisher - and that has huge ramifications

I tried Stadia, Google's big play to conquer video games. It's really promising, but there's still too much we don't know.

NOW WATCH: Nintendo Switch is the fastest-selling console of the current generation - here's why Nintendo is dominating video games

See Also:

I tried Stadia, Google's big play to conquer video games. It's really promising, but there's still too much we don't know.

Google just unveiled Stadia, its ambitious attempt to upend the video-game industry and take on Xbox and PlayStation. Here's everything we know.

Google just unveiled its Netflix-like video-game platform Stadia

urn:contentItem:5KRW-JYC1-DY0W-420C-00000-00Google's WH Fast Pass; Google's Wall Street Hire; Big Tech Retirement Gamble; What the Tech?!; Neil's Spiel; RadioShack Auctioning2015-03-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisGoogle's WH Fast Pass; Google's Wall Street Hire; Big Tech Retirement Gamble; What the Tech?!; Neil's Spiel; RadioShack AuctioningLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN HOST: Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto. Glad to have you.

And who knew Google has its own fast pass to the White House? I'm talking very fast, fast pass and apparently, one that never expires. You should be so lucky with yours at Disney because Google employees get on a lot of rides at this White House park -- try 230 of them since the president first took office.

Now, that roughly (INAUDIBLE) about one a week and apparently, they weren't all going for the ride. Many of these meetings came as the government was wrapping up its antitrust investigation into Google. So awkward.

Now, I don't know. But here's what I do know. The Federal Trade Commission eventually closed that investigation. Google agreed to make some voluntary changes to its business practices. But you needn't Google the term "quid pro quo" to know something doesn't smell right because I don't know about you but this kind of stuff doesn't happen to us. Taxpayers don't get these kind of breaks or fast passes. In fact, for most businesses, it is far more common to be shut out of the White House than ever get so much as a kind word from the White House.

But again, that is just me.

Steve Moore wants to shut this ride down. But Basil Smikle says it is (INAUDIBLE), I should say it's not such a bad ride.

You don't like the sound of any of it?

STEVE MOORE, HERITAGE CHIEF ECONOMIST: I'm old enough to remember when Google and Apple and Microsoft and Netflix didn't even have lobbying operations in Washington, you know? And the high tech community in Silicon Valley just said, "Leave us alone. We'll do our thing and you do your thing." And now, they have these massive lobbying operations in Washington. And it's basically the Google administration right now. I mean, they (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: But they're not alone, I guess, because their sheer size, the - - it looks a little more obvious.

BASIL SMIKLE, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, I think to your point exactly, tech -- the government and our legislature always lags behind technology. And right now, these companies are sort of ruling the world. It's not surprising.

MOORE: (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: So why wasn't he meeting with these Google guys before the launch of the Affordable Care Act (INAUDIBLE)?

SMIKLE: Well, it's not surprising that he's meeting with them now. Look at all (INAUDIBLE) that we've been talking about in the last year. We talked about.

CAVUTO: The sheer number of meetings, (INAUDIBLE), come on.

SMIKLE: .we've talked about -- we've talked about immigration and they're certainly going to lobby for high school workers.

CAVUTO: One a week.

SMIKLE: We talked about net neutrality. That's going to be a key issue.

CAVUTO: I know, I know. (INAUDIBLE).

SMIKLE: The problem is -- the point is that they have a lot of stuff to talk about and (INAUDIBLE).

MOORE: They have. (INAUDIBLE) problem.

CAVUTO: All right.

SMIKLE: I don't begrudge them but using their resources in trying to push (INAUDIBLE).

MOORE: The interesting thing about the net neutrality issue is that Google was on the side of net neutrality at the beginning and then -- then saw the government got their fangs.

CAVUTO: Well, it evolved. They evolved as they've been getting bigger. (INAUDIBLE). If George Bush were doing this with defense contractors every week, you would be -- flip a gasket, as would I.

SMIKLE: I probably would but I would -- instead of pointing to George Bush, I'd point to Ronald Reagan. Think about the coziness that he had with some of the media companies 'cause they -- he actually sparked a lot of this sort of consolidation in media under his watch. You had more companies than ever before in history and the mergers and acquisitions. So that's (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: I think it's fair to say during that time though, he did not have a cozy relationship with the media. They were blistering him every day.

SMIKLE: But he did with big business and we forgave him that or others forgave him that. So.

CAVUTO: Not the Washington Post.

MOORE: This is the most (INAUDIBLE) situation of all though. You have big - $4 trillion government and you have these massive companies like Google -- I think Google's the biggest company in the world right now in terms of revenues -- and you put them together and bad things happen. We want big government and big business to stay on top.

CAVUTO: See, but I agree, Basil, but I think it's fine for a CEO -- CEOs -- to meet at the White House. I think he gets a little problematic when it turns into like "Skip the pass, you can just walk in through the front gate."

SMIKLE: Well, I don't know if it was that -- if they had that kind of access. But the reality.

CAVUTO: It all comes back to bite you. Remember what happened to JPMorgan Chase. Jamie Dimon could just waltz into the Oval Office anytime he wanted. As soon as he started getting attacked critical, not only did they take the fast pass away, before you know it, the firm was facing billions of dollars (INAUDIBLE).

SMIKLE: So are you saying that the Bush administration shouldn't have allowed him in as much as they should've?

CAVUTO: I'm saying not every week. That's what I'm saying. I just think that that gets a little weird.

SMIKLE: Well, I think as businesses grow, as industries go, I would imagine that this occurred with the auto industry at some point -- that as they become such huge (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Talk to others. Talk to others. Talk to others.

SMIKLE: When they have such a huge role in our business, in our industry, they're going to be meeting with government officials (INAUDIBLE) all the time.

CAVUTO: But it's the same thing I said at this president (INAUDIBLE) meeting with the likes of Al Sharpton (INAUDIBLE) the racial issue -- meet with other representatives from points of view. But be fair and balanced. He is now choosing "I'm going to be fair if I focus on Google, I focus on Apple, and I kind of ignore everyone else."

SMIKLE: But who else is driving our conversations about technology (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Well, those guys will never get the chance. Those guys will never get the chance.

MOORE: There are thousands and thousands of small businesses in the technology industry, by the way, biting at the heels of Google and I guarantee you, most of them do not have a lobbyist. I'm sure they don't have a (INAUDIBLE). But that's -- I have a little bit take on this thing. You, Neil. I mean, I just think when the government tries to regulate the high tech industry, as you said, you put it very well. There are three generations behind where this industry is at.

CAVUTO: But what did I say about regulating technology? I didn't (INAUDIBLE).

MOORE: No, no. I just -- I just mean -- I think the problem.

CAVUTO: (INAUDIBLE).

MOORE: .of course, Google's going to have all these lobbyists because the government is sticking its fingers in everything that they do.

SMIKLE: But I agree the small businesses should have a role at the table.

MOORE: No. No, no. That's not my point.

SMIKLE: I know but I do (INAUDIBLE) -- I do think -- I do think that small businesses (INAUDIBLE) -- should have -- should have (INAUDIBLE).

MOORE: The government -- there's too many of them. There are millions of small businesses. There's not enough Lincoln Bedrooms.

CAVUTO: He makes more sense than you do. That's scary, right there.

SMIKLE: That's scary, wow.

CAVUTO: Guys, seriously, thank you both very, very much.

In the meantime, no wonder so many want to (INAUDIBLE) Google. With connections like those, who wouldn't?

Now, add Ruth Porat onto that growing list of eager Google recruits. But Ms. Porat isn't just any recruit, is she? She's the chief financial officer of investment bank Morgan Stanley, one of the most powerful women -- actually, one of the most powerful anyone on Wall Street. And now, she's going to become CFO of Google.

Add her to a growing list of Wall Streeters going to tech including a top Goldman strategist to Twitter or -- continuing with this revolving door thing -- former Obama advisor David Plouffe to Uber and Jay Carney to Amazon.

Forget what this means to tech. What does this mean to what's left of Wall Street?

Scott Martin says not much but given the way the White House, he says, has been bashing Wall Street, not much we can do to stop it.

The allure, I think, for a lot of them is technology's cool, there's actually even more money in it which is hard to believe because you're sinfully rich enough but what's going on here?

SCOTT MARTIN, UNITED ADVISORS CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST: Sinfully rich. Yes, that's why I describe myself on Twitter--. Neil, it's tough. I mean, the dreaded brain drain in the financial industry is upon us. I mean, the financial industry, the markets couldn't even keep around a nice lady like Veronica Vain -- look her up -- sports fans being interesting because the allure is not there anymore, Neil. Really, I mean, it is the technology sector. It is all these cool things that are going on outside of this once-big structural firm that was Wall Street, that where all the banks are (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: I think it's money, Scott. I really do think it's money because as much as the financial industry pays, it's chump change in comparison to the stake you take when a technology company does well, goes well, between options and advances and stock, I mean you become a gazilionaire a lot quicker there than you ever could on Wall Street.

MARTIN: You do. I think Wall Street tough too, Neil, also thanks to the administration, thanks to the financial crisis, has a little bit of an image problem still. In fact, I'd argue that the financial crisis, our financial situation, for a lot of thee banks is not near what it was before the crisis. So you have the perception on both Main Street and some of the certainly people in D.C. that say, "You know what? The banks are still doing things wrong and to your point about the financials of them, Dodd-Frank, (INAUDIBLE) regulations, all things that are out there now -- Elizabeth Warren being a big party in the Democrats' side of.

CAVUTO: No, I think the bloom is off the rose. You're absolutely right on that as you are in these issues. And I think the latest telltale sign, college graduates, MBA graduates used to be by overwhelmingly flock to the -- Wall Street. Now, it's half and half and that other half is going to technology.

MARTIN: And here's the ironic thing, right? Now, the only reason that you probably like your bank or that you can deal with them is because the technology behind it allows you to do what you want to do. But if you work at that bank, if you have that high-paying job on Wall Stree which isn't as high-paying as it once was, that doesn't hold its same mustard as it did, say, five, 10 years ago,.

CAVUTO: You're right. Scott, you will be the last guy standing and all the money will be yours.

All right. Scott.

MARTIN: That's a scary thought. See you later.

CAVUTO: That is scary. Thank you, my friend.

In the meantime, Wall Street's not the only one with a Silicon Valley problem. You might have one.

It's true because Fidelity and other money managers are striking deals with tech startups like Uber and Pinterest who load up your retirement portfolio. And I bet you didn't even know it.

And what's even scary to Larry Winget is they're doing it in companies that don't have any money or (INAUDIBLE) of making money anytime soon.

Larry, the argument for this is that, "Hey, we're spreading our bets. We're giving you a more diversified portfolio. We don't know the percentage that they pour in to these kind of companies but we know they never did before." So what do you make of this?

LARRY WINGET, "GROW A PAIR" AUTHOR: Well, I wouldn't find it especially alarming if they're pouring big percentages into it if you're a retiree and you're counting on this to be your retirement fund to live on because it's pure speculation what these tech startups are going to be worth. They value them but that value is not based on publicly-released financial statements. They've never been traded anywhere before. These are privately-held companies. And from a guy like me, it would just be a made-up number. When I look at some of the stuff that's out there -- look at Uber, for instance. In mid-2013, it was supposedly worth $3.5 billion. Now, the valuation is over $40 billion. A thousand percent when the S&P 500 is up 28 percent. How did they come up with a 1,000 percent growth in less than two years? That would bother me.

CAVUTO: All right. Well, they could also move on to the government, if that's -- if they don't make (INAUDIBLE). But do you think they shouldn't invest in this (INAUDIBLE), that it shouldn't' be part of any portfolio or do you think when it comes to people and their retirement money -- 'cause a lot (INAUDIBLE), this is multiyear, multi-decade money, that there shouldn't be a little bit of aggressive investment in there anyway.

WINGET: I have no problem with there being a very small percentage and some of them are saying -- some of the mutual funds are saying you will only be a very small percentage. The good side is if it's very small, you're not going to lose a lot of money. (END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: I don't know, never, never sounds like maybe to me. Stacy emails, "I just watched your interview with Mr. Romney, it was good, I sure wish he would have made it into office."

Tony in Vermont, "My comment on your Facebook post about Mitt Romney had 600 likes, in first 30 minutes, did I just go viral?" No, you are just hitching along for ride.

Meanwhile, Henry via centurylink.net, "Neil, for a long time, several times, I have written you about criticism about your constant interruptions and also your stupid laugh.

Today, your interview with Governor Mitt Romney was the latest in your annoying actions. So I have designated you as the newest on my list of men a carried for a long time as the least admirable three men in the world, the title you are now on is jerk."

Well, at least, you didn't call me fat. By the way, you got to tell me, who are other two? Buffalo businessman, Karl Paladino weighing in on 2016 and Mitt Romney.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CARL PALADINO (R), FORMER NEW YORK GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE: We need a guy who can create jobs that understands means of creating jobs does not side with 1 percent against the 99 percent. The Republican base, that is there, many of them did not come out for Romney, they done vote. That hurt him.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Tommy in North Carolina, not a fan of Carl's, "Alan Grayson is a very good businessman. That does not mean he is sane. Grayson, Donald Trump, and Carl Paladino should form a club." That would be a wealthy club.

Russ emails, "Good to see Paladino back. Good ideas as always." Finally, this from Jim, "Neil, I see on the news that Hillary has a new e-mail account. Since she isn't using the old one, can we see the server?"

You know, well, I guess, she is not using it. Thanks for watching. "STRANGE INHERITANCE" right now.

END
