Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5FKV-T6T1-JB20-G202-00000-00Google's WH Fast Pass; Google's Wall Street Hire; Big Tech Retirement Gamble; What the Tech?!; Neil's Spiel; RadioShack Auctioning Info; Senator Thune Repeal Death Tax; Taylor Swift Buys Porn Domains2015-03-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisCAVUTO6:00 PM ESTSteve Moore, Basil Smikle, Scott Martin, Larry Winget, Shama Hyder, Rick Santorum, John ThuneNEWSBusiness032501cb.223Google's WH Fast Pass; Google's Wall Street Hire; Big Tech Retirement Gamble; What the Tech?!; Neil's Spiel; RadioShack Auctioning Info; Senator Thune Repeal Death Tax; Taylor Swift Buys Porn DomainsNeil Cavuto, Kennedy, Jamie Colby

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN HOST: Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto. Glad to have you.

And who knew Google has its own fast pass to the White House? I'm talking very fast, fast pass and apparently, one that never expires. You should be so lucky with yours at Disney because Google employees get on a lot of rides at this White House park -- try 230 of them since the president first took office.

Now, that roughly (INAUDIBLE) about one a week and apparently, they weren't all going for the ride. Many of these meetings came as the government was wrapping up its antitrust investigation into Google. So awkward.

Now, I don't know. But here's what I do know. The Federal Trade Commission eventually closed that investigation. Google agreed to make some voluntary changes to its business practices. But you needn't Google the term "quid pro quo" to know something doesn't smell right because I don't know about you but this kind of stuff doesn't happen to us. Taxpayers don't get these kind of breaks or fast passes. In fact, for most businesses, it is far more common to be shut out of the White House than ever get so much as a kind word from the White House.

But again, that is just me.

Steve Moore wants to shut this ride down. But Basil Smikle says it is (INAUDIBLE), I should say it's not such a bad ride.

You don't like the sound of any of it?

STEVE MOORE, HERITAGE CHIEF ECONOMIST: I'm old enough to remember when Google and Apple and Microsoft and Netflix didn't even have lobbying operations in Washington, you know? And the high tech community in Silicon Valley just said, "Leave us alone. We'll do our thing and you do your thing." And now, they have these massive lobbying operations in Washington. And it's basically the Google administration right now. I mean, they (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: But they're not alone, I guess, because their sheer size, the - - it looks a little more obvious.

BASIL SMIKLE, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, I think to your point exactly, tech -- the government and our legislature always lags behind technology. And right now, these companies are sort of ruling the world. It's not surprising.

MOORE: (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: So why wasn't he meeting with these Google guys before the launch of the Affordable Care Act (INAUDIBLE)?

SMIKLE: Well, it's not surprising that he's meeting with them now. Look at all (INAUDIBLE) that we've been talking about in the last year. We talked about.

CAVUTO: The sheer number of meetings, (INAUDIBLE), come on.

SMIKLE: .we've talked about -- we've talked about immigration and they're certainly going to lobby for high school workers.

CAVUTO: One a week.

SMIKLE: We talked about net neutrality. That's going to be a key issue.

CAVUTO: I know, I know. (INAUDIBLE).

SMIKLE: The problem is -- the point is that they have a lot of stuff to talk about and (INAUDIBLE).

MOORE: They have. (INAUDIBLE) problem.

CAVUTO: All right.

SMIKLE: I don't begrudge them but using their resources in trying to push (INAUDIBLE).

MOORE: The interesting thing about the net neutrality issue is that Google was on the side of net neutrality at the beginning and then -- then saw the government got their fangs.

CAVUTO: Well, it evolved. They evolved as they've been getting bigger. (INAUDIBLE). If George Bush were doing this with defense contractors every week, you would be -- flip a gasket, as would I.

SMIKLE: I probably would but I would -- instead of pointing to George Bush, I'd point to Ronald Reagan. Think about the coziness that he had with some of the media companies 'cause they -- he actually sparked a lot of this sort of consolidation in media under his watch. You had more companies than ever before in history and the mergers and acquisitions. So that's (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: I think it's fair to say during that time though, he did not have a cozy relationship with the media. They were blistering him every day.

SMIKLE: But he did with big business and we forgave him that or others forgave him that. So.

CAVUTO: Not the Washington Post.

MOORE: This is the most (INAUDIBLE) situation of all though. You have big - $4 trillion government and you have these massive companies like Google -- I think Google's the biggest company in the world right now in terms of revenues -- and you put them together and bad things happen. We want big government and big business to stay on top.

CAVUTO: See, but I agree, Basil, but I think it's fine for a CEO -- CEOs -- to meet at the White House. I think he gets a little problematic when it turns into like "Skip the pass, you can just walk in through the front gate."

SMIKLE: Well, I don't know if it was that -- if they had that kind of access. But the reality.

CAVUTO: It all comes back to bite you. Remember what happened to JPMorgan Chase. Jamie Dimon could just waltz into the Oval Office anytime he wanted. As soon as he started getting attacked critical, not only did they take the fast pass away, before you know it, the firm was facing billions of dollars (INAUDIBLE).

SMIKLE: So are you saying that the Bush administration shouldn't have allowed him in as much as they should've?

CAVUTO: I'm saying not every week. That's what I'm saying. I just think that that gets a little weird.

SMIKLE: Well, I think as businesses grow, as industries go, I would imagine that this occurred with the auto industry at some point -- that as they become such huge (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Talk to others. Talk to others. Talk to others.

SMIKLE: When they have such a huge role in our business, in our industry, they're going to be meeting with government officials (INAUDIBLE) all the time.

CAVUTO: But it's the same thing I said at this president (INAUDIBLE) meeting with the likes of Al Sharpton (INAUDIBLE) the racial issue -- meet with other representatives from points of view. But be fair and balanced. He is now choosing "I'm going to be fair if I focus on Google, I focus on Apple, and I kind of ignore everyone else."

SMIKLE: But who else is driving our conversations about technology (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Well, those guys will never get the chance. Those guys will never get the chance.

MOORE: There are thousands and thousands of small businesses in the technology industry, by the way, biting at the heels of Google and I guarantee you, most of them do not have a lobbyist. I'm sure they don't have a (INAUDIBLE). But that's -- I have a little bit take on this thing. You, Neil. I mean, I just think when the government tries to regulate the high tech industry, as you said, you put it very well. There are three generations behind where this industry is at.

CAVUTO: But what did I say about regulating technology? I didn't (INAUDIBLE).

MOORE: No, no. I just -- I just mean -- I think the problem.

CAVUTO: (INAUDIBLE).

MOORE: .of course, Google's going to have all these lobbyists because the government is sticking its fingers in everything that they do.

SMIKLE: But I agree the small businesses should have a role at the table.

MOORE: No. No, no. That's not my point.

SMIKLE: I know but I do (INAUDIBLE) -- I do think -- I do think that small businesses (INAUDIBLE) -- should have -- should have (INAUDIBLE).

MOORE: The government -- there's too many of them. There are millions of small businesses. There's not enough Lincoln Bedrooms.

CAVUTO: He makes more sense than you do. That's scary, right there.

SMIKLE: That's scary, wow.

CAVUTO: Guys, seriously, thank you both very, very much.

In the meantime, no wonder so many want to (INAUDIBLE) Google. With connections like those, who wouldn't?

Now, add Ruth Porat onto that growing list of eager Google recruits. But Ms. Porat isn't just any recruit, is she? She's the chief financial officer of investment bank Morgan Stanley, one of the most powerful women -- actually, one of the most powerful anyone on Wall Street. And now, she's going to become CFO of Google.

Add her to a growing list of Wall Streeters going to tech including a top Goldman strategist to Twitter or -- continuing with this revolving door thing -- former Obama advisor David Plouffe to Uber and Jay Carney to Amazon.

Forget what this means to tech. What does this mean to what's left of Wall Street?

Scott Martin says not much but given the way the White House, he says, has been bashing Wall Street, not much we can do to stop it.

The allure, I think, for a lot of them is technology's cool, there's actually even more money in it which is hard to believe because you're sinfully rich enough but what's going on here?

SCOTT MARTIN, UNITED ADVISORS CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST: Sinfully rich. Yes, that's why I describe myself on Twitter--. Neil, it's tough. I mean, the dreaded brain drain in the financial industry is upon us. I mean, the financial industry, the markets couldn't even keep around a nice lady like Veronica Vain -- look her up -- sports fans being interesting because the allure is not there anymore, Neil. Really, I mean, it is the technology sector. It is all these cool things that are going on outside of this once-big structural firm that was Wall Street, that where all the banks are (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: I think it's money, Scott. I really do think it's money because as much as the financial industry pays, it's chump change in comparison to the stake you take when a technology company does well, goes well, between options and advances and stock, I mean you become a gazilionaire a lot quicker there than you ever could on Wall Street.

MARTIN: You do. I think Wall Street tough too, Neil, also thanks to the administration, thanks to the financial crisis, has a little bit of an image problem still. In fact, I'd argue that the financial crisis, our financial situation, for a lot of thee banks is not near what it was before the crisis. So you have the perception on both Main Street and some of the certainly people in D.C. that say, "You know what? The banks are still doing things wrong and to your point about the financials of them, Dodd-Frank, (INAUDIBLE) regulations, all things that are out there now -- Elizabeth Warren being a big party in the Democrats' side of.

CAVUTO: No, I think the bloom is off the rose. You're absolutely right on that as you are in these issues. And I think the latest telltale sign, college graduates, MBA graduates used to be by overwhelmingly flock to the -- Wall Street. Now, it's half and half and that other half is going to technology.

MARTIN: And here's the ironic thing, right? Now, the only reason that you probably like your bank or that you can deal with them is because the technology behind it allows you to do what you want to do. But if you work at that bank, if you have that high-paying job on Wall Stree which isn't as high-paying as it once was, that doesn't hold its same mustard as it did, say, five, 10 years ago,.

CAVUTO: You're right. Scott, you will be the last guy standing and all the money will be yours.

All right. Scott.

MARTIN: That's a scary thought. See you later.

CAVUTO: That is scary. Thank you, my friend.

In the meantime, Wall Street's not the only one with a Silicon Valley problem. You might have one.

It's true because Fidelity and other money managers are striking deals with tech startups like Uber and Pinterest who load up your retirement portfolio. And I bet you didn't even know it.

And what's even scary to Larry Winget is they're doing it in companies that don't have any money or (INAUDIBLE) of making money anytime soon.

Larry, the argument for this is that, "Hey, we're spreading our bets. We're giving you a more diversified portfolio. We don't know the percentage that they pour in to these kind of companies but we know they never did before." So what do you make of this?

LARRY WINGET, "GROW A PAIR" AUTHOR: Well, I wouldn't find it especially alarming if they're pouring big percentages into it if you're a retiree and you're counting on this to be your retirement fund to live on because it's pure speculation what these tech startups are going to be worth. They value them but that value is not based on publicly-released financial statements. They've never been traded anywhere before. These are privately-held companies. And from a guy like me, it would just be a made-up number. When I look at some of the stuff that's out there -- look at Uber, for instance. In mid-2013, it was supposedly worth $3.5 billion. Now, the valuation is over $40 billion. A thousand percent when the S&P 500 is up 28 percent. How did they come up with a 1,000 percent growth in less than two years? That would bother me.

CAVUTO: All right. Well, they could also move on to the government, if that's -- if they don't make (INAUDIBLE). But do you think they shouldn't invest in this (INAUDIBLE), that it shouldn't' be part of any portfolio or do you think when it comes to people and their retirement money -- 'cause a lot (INAUDIBLE), this is multiyear, multi-decade money, that there shouldn't be a little bit of aggressive investment in there anyway.

WINGET: I have no problem with there being a very small percentage and some of them are saying -- some of the mutual funds are saying you will only be a very small percentage. The good side is if it's very small, you're not going to lose a lot of money. But the bad side is even if they make a lot of money and -- for instance, Uber is worth a thousand times more than it was a couple of years ago, you're probably not going to make a lot of money either. It all comes down to how old you are (INAUDIBLE). If you're 40 years old, you could -= and you have most of your earning years ahead of you, you could afford to be a little more risky. If you're in your 60s, you can't afford that kind of risk. Yes, there's a lot of money to be made but there's always the other side of that -- there's a lot of money to be lost and I don't want any of that money as I approach retirement to be mine when it comes to losing it.

CAVUTO: Well, not everyone can write an incredible bestseller one after the other like you. People have to hedge their beds.

Larry Winget, thank you very, very much.

WINGET: Thank you.

CAVUTO: Well, holy moly. With Ted Cruz and Mike Huckabee and Ben Carson likely carving up the Christian vote, are you starting to think that Rick Santorum doesn't have a prayer?

Rick's here to say "You don't have a clue."

And you think making cakes is about as far as 3D printers can go? Then this just takes the cake. Now, they're printing construction guys right of their jobs.

What the Tech?! What do we do when tech turns on us?

CAVUTO: All right.

Well, who needs an architect or construction expert if a 3D printer can spit out what they do and in a fraction of the time. What the tech?! What just happened?

Up first in the segment that is taking the nation by storm, the storm over these cool 3D printers that came in peace but are now apparently peacefully printing out pink slips for many in the building industry. I warned you, America.

To tech watcher Shama Hyder on what this is all about.

Shana, what's going -- what can these printers do that's got so many in the construction industry going nuts?

SHAMA HYDER, MARKETING ZEN CEO: Well, these printers are pretty cool in a lot of ways because they do have the capability of building an entire building. I mean, they're -- they -- they can -- they're stackable. You -- so if you have a job in the construction industry which involves hitting a nail with a hammer over and over again, you should be scared because chances are, some of the printers are going to take that over. But really, if you're.

CAVUTO: And do that as well?

HYDER: They're going to do that but they're really good at repetitive tasks. But when it comes to strategically building something, you still need human minds behind it. So this is the whole (INAUDIBLE) we've been hearing for so long -- is technology replacing humans? No. It's really not.

CAVUTO: I saw "2001 Space Odyssey." I remember how a certain pod bay door wasn't opened so I know how this ends. Where's this all going?

HYDER: This has a different ending though.

CAVUTO: Oh, really?

HYDER: Yes, it does and I'll tell you -- because technology (INAUDIBLE) can really assist people. I think we'll see homes becoming cheaper in many ways which would -- I mean, I'd appreciate that. That'd be great. But also imagine in.

CAVUTO: If you had a job to buy the home.

HYDER: That's right. But imagine in places where it's war-torn or a storm comes through and totally demolishes that community. Having something like this could mean that people have shelter within days, within hours, and that's powerful.

CAVUTO: All right. As long as they don't advance into the TV news business (INAUDIBLE).

All right. Next up, a workout suit that will intensify your workout. Forget three hours sweating up a storm, they say you put this thing on, 20 minutes, you have the same effect and you're done. Now, if they can get that puppy down to 20 seconds, sign me up. But in the meantime, Shama, how does this thing even work?

HYDER: So it's pretty neat. It's got electrodes that go on your skin essentially through this body suit which looks just like a normal gym suit, something you might wear to workout. But essentially, it works with the muscles so they work out harder. This really neat (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Well, how is it -- is it telling you "You're not working hard enough", or is it just dragging your hand to the punching bag?

HYDER: No, you do have to put in the motion. You do have to put in the work, right, but it essentially.

CAVUTO: Oh, so I actually have to work-out.

HYDER: You do -- you do -- you do have to get up. You do have to work- out but it amplifies it.

CAVUTO: Well, that's the problem. All right. All right.

HYDER: Right. So there's no -- there's no magic here but it will amplify the effects you get.

CAVUTO: In other words, you get a lot more done in a shorter period.

HYDER: Absolutely. But are you going to see like the normal mom going to do this after dropping the kids off and going to gym? No. But for athletes, for people in the sports industry where every little edge counts, this is going to be huge.

CAVUTO: Well, apparently, I'll have more time on my hands after a 3D printer takes my place. It just might work out.

Meanwhile, this is incredible because after that airbus crash in the south of France, for rival Boeing, it's an announcement that might be eerily time because the company has now uncovered two black boxes in the French Alps. That is, the company behind this crash. The problem is one is very badly damaged. The other is missing its memory card.

But what Boeing has come up with might make black boxes themselves obsolete, totally unnecessary. The airplane maker just patented a force field of lasers. What that would do is make a plane impenetrable to missiles or outside forces. So let me be clear here, it wouldn't prevent the kind of crash we saw this week in France but it might have stopped that Malaysian jet from being shotdown over the Ukraine last year.

So Shama, I guess the only issue here would be the expense for this, right?

HYDER: Yes. I mean, this is going to be expensive but innovation generally is until it's not, right? But anytime you're talking electromagnetic fields, you're talking about new technology that the U.S. government uses now that can see through concrete walls. And so, this isn't necessarily new technology.

CAVUTO: And it doesn't interrupt to them -- and that static field doesn't' interrupt with the cockpit controls or any of the device.

HYDER: And so, I mean, this is all the stuff that they're going to have to work out, obviously. It's very, very early stages but yes. It's good. It's going to be a huge expense but as they -- as they tinker with it, as they play with it, it'll obviously get cheaper and hopefully make the world safer.

CAVUTO: Yes. There was a big push -- I mean -- after this shoot-down that "Hey, we have to help or retrofit airlines with this sort of technology." Now, again, to your point, it depends on the expense. But I kind of think something like this is just a matter of time.

HYDER: It is. It's absolutely a matter of time. And once they test it out, they'll get better and better with it. There's certain things that'll make technology overall cheaper like battery life. That's something Google's working very hard right now on. If they can figure out a way for batteries to be cheaper, last longer, all of this technology becomes easier, cheaper, faster.

CAVUTO: All right. We'll watch closely, Shama. Thank you very, very much.

HYDER: My pleasure.

CAVUTO: Well, saints preserve us. We've got a lot of saints in this presidential race. Men of God who have no problem talking about God. Now, four years ago, only Rick Santorum was doing that. Now, a fee other presidential wannabees art harping in. Harp. (INAUDIBLE).

Anyway, think Rick is losing the religious right? Why don't I ask Rick myself? Because he's here and only here, next.

CAVUTO: Boy, this just boils me.

Remember when I was chatting with Mitt Romney yesterday about this likely very crowded Republican presidential field? Now, I said it is so crowded, good luck, Republicans, deciding on a nominee by convention time, like they did back with him, back 2012. Come 2016, it's not going to happen. Now, he scoffed.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: If there s potion by vote -- primaries -- falling out, you could get to a situation which begs the issue, would you entertain the party coming to you and saying, "Governor, we're at a draw here."

MITT ROMNEY, (R) 2012 PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: First, that's not going to happen. Two, I'm not.

CAVUTO: It's happened before.

ROMNEY: Two, I'm not an entertainer. And three, that was a long time ago that happened. Look, we're going to have our nominee and I'm one of those people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Well, he may say never, never, never. But girls told me that all the time in high school before my mother finally said yes and we went to the prom together.

Anyway, my point is this -- there are going to be a lot of Republicans vying for this presidential nomination. I'm thinking at least a dozen, probably more. Let's say half of them -- half of them -- stick it out right to the spring. And so many of these primaries (INAUDIBLE) delegates based on your portion of the vote. That means they're all competing for the same number of delegates being portioned out. It gets to be mathematically impossible for any one man or woman to amass the delegates necessary by the time the convention gets to Cleveland.

So consider just those vying for the evangelical vote. Back in 2008, it was just Mike Huckabee. Four years later, it was pretty much just Rick Santorum. But this time, it'll be Rick and Mike and Ted Cruz and maybe Ben Carson and maybe Marco Rubio making his Roman Catholic claim to Christian conservatives. You get the picture? It's a crowded picture. It's a crowded race.

To Rick Santorum who joins us on the phone whether he's praying a little bit more these days.

Senator, what do you think?

RICK SANTORUM, (R) FMR. PENNSYLVANIA SENATOR (ON THE PHONE): I can always use a few more prayers, Neil. Thank you.

CAVUTO: Well.

SANTORUM: Look, I don't -- I think that it's way too early. I mean, if you go back to four years ago, there were a whole lot of other people who were considering -- you talk about Rick Santorum being the only person (INAUDIBLE)I think Michele Bachmann and Herman Cain and Rick Perry and Newt Gingrich, there're a whole lot of people who were trying to appeal to those voters that we eventually did very well with. That's -- it's going to be a --it's office competitive. It has been competitive in the past and this thing will winnow itself down. There isn't -- there isn't enough air in the -- in the chamber for 12 or 13 candidates to make it for a few weeks. It will -- it will narrow down in the first few weeks and the first few primaries.

CAVUTO: All right. I know you're a very religious guy but I'm married to math. I am a numbers geek although I try to be decent and the numbers just don't add up. I mean, in other words, just to get to the 1200, 1300 delegates, you're going to need ultimately what the states decide on how much is a portion in each state. It's going to be an uphill climb and if someone stays in, even a significant group through April or May -- which is an (INAUDIBLE) possibility, it gets to be prohibitive. Does that make you think there is a possibility because as you know, Senator, when you're a good historian, this used to be more than norm -- multiple balance and recent history where it's a single ballot - where that could happen again?

SANTORUM: I think -- it certainly, it could've happened last time and there was -- there was several candidates who (INAUDIBLE) but as you know, if we go back and look at the last time, there were several candidates and it narrowed down after a few weeks. It narrowed down to really two who had a possibility of winning. And that is likely to happen this time also. But if it doesn't happen, as I said last time around, it's not the end of the world. The bottom line is that the primary process -- let it work, let the competition work, and if there is a real division, then we'll go to something that I'm certainly not worried about. I think an interesting -- a convention where we have ideas out there and we have candidates pretty (INAUDIBLE) the different visions for the country in a dynamic way that -- and captivate a nation. I mean, we haven't had a competitive Republican or Democratic primary convention and in a couple of generations. This would be -- I think it would exciting (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Well, I'm not ready to bet with you. I think it's going to happen. You could very well be in that mix. But enough about me. Back to you and the guest I had on with me talking about you, including Foster Friess -- big friend of yours, big backer of yours. And I raised with him the fact that he also likes some other guys in the Party.

This is Foster Friess from a few days ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Now, I know you placed your bets and your support behind Rick Santorum but you also have been seen in the company of Senator Cruz. Were you hedging your bets?

FOSTER FRIESS, GOP FUNDRAISER: I'm a Rick Santorum guy and I'm just so impressed with our entire field and Ted Cruz is one amazing human being but the challenge that all of us face is how do we get the establishment and the tea party to kiss and make up because if that doesn't happen, we're dead in the water as Republicans.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Senator, is he leaving you?

SANTORUM: Is he what, Neil? (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Was he hinting he could drop you?

SANTORUM: No. I mean, I just talked to Foster today, as a matter of fact. No. No. Foster's a good friend and a great supporter. And by the way, we've got -- we're building a very strong team. I mean, it's really exciting to see so many people who are encouraging us to get into this race. We haven't made any decisions of that yet (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: But he hasn't said anything to you, Senator, where he says, "I love you dearly, Rick. You're an honorable great man but at the first sign of stumbling, I'm going to leave you in a heartbeat"?

SANTORUM: Oh, my goodness. No, I don't know. Foster and I are very, very close personal friends as well as (INAUDIBLE) in all aspects the same. And so -- now I'm not -- that's the last thing I'm concerned about. I -- what I'm concerned about is making sure that and before we enter into this thing that we've got a big, strong team that we can -- we can run the kind of race that's going to be a winning race, not only in the primary but also in the general--. Do what Foster's--. With Foster, I talked about this a lot.

We have to have a message that's a unifying message. Not just between the Tea Party and the establishment, but you know reaching out, and bridging this country together. I think so many people are sick of the division that is going on in this country and they are looking for someone with a fresh message to bring us together.

CAVUTO: All right, we'll watch closely, Senator. It's always a pleasure. Thank you very, very much.

SANTORUM: Thank you, Neil.

CAVUTO: Rick Santorum.

In the meantime, I want you to think quick. Taylor Swift, RadioShack, one is buying up porn sites with all of their nasty stuff. The other is selling off anything that is not nailed down, including your personal stuff. Which one is sexy and which one is just sad? We shake it up, you decide.

CAVUTO: Maybe it's just me, but I think this is RadioShack's version of looking under couch cushions for some spare change, only it's customer data the bankrupt retailers cashing in and I bet you have no idea it's even going on.

Well, it is going on. Apparently, it is all perfectly legal like selling mailing list to companies even though RadioShack is on the verge of no longer even being a company. Well, Kennedy is worried RadioShack is not alone, not a fan of this sort of thing, right?

KENNEDY "KENNEDY" HOST ON FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: Neil, very good to be here with you today. RadioShack --

CAVUTO: Why do you sound like you don't mean that?

KENNEDY: I so mean that. You know that I'm --

CAVUTO: Continue.

KENNEDY: -- I baked you a ham loaf not long ago out of deep adoration and affection.

CAVUTO: Yes, so what is this? Everyone has a list, right?

KENNEDY: They do. Everyone has a list and if you are dumb enough to go to a store, and give them your address and your email address, and your phone number and your name because you want to be a part of their gift club, and the fan club, and everything else.

That's on you because what do you think they are doing with it. Do you think they are just going to luck into a safe?

CAVUTO: But when you order stuff online, someone is scarfing that up information.

KENNEDY: Of course, they are.

CAVUTO: Not just the company you're --

KENNEDY: No, I mean, that is the price of doing business in an electronic age. I get that. I accept that responsibility as a consumer. I am not wild about it. Whatever --

CAVUTO: So RadioShack, it's selling everything but the kitchen sink, right?

KENNEDY: Do you know why? My husband pointed this out this weekend because they were dismantling a RadioShack sign where we live in the west side of Los Angeles. He said, of course, they are going out of business. It is called RadioShack, what is the last time you bought a radio?

CAVUTO: Internet shack or something.

KENNEDY: Well, it's so fashion backward.

CAVUTO: You know, it is legal, lawyers tell me, legal what they are doing, not their cup of tea, but it is legal. But you --

KENNEDY: Attorneys general in Texas and Tennessee actually disagree with that because in Texas, it violates some of the privacy laws there. So it will be up to --

CAVUTO: So companies that sells these as back and forth, they can't do that.

KENNEDY: And depending on the state, and that is what a republic is, that is fine 92. If you want to live in a state of Texas --

CAVUTO: That is us. There you go.

KENNEDY: Indeed, you are a 100 percent correct as per usual, Neil Cavuto.

CAVUTO: Thank you very much. So, I think RadioShack will do it someone will buy the list, and I don't know who because it is a dwindling list, some of the names go back to 1980s. I thought many of them are dead.

KENNEDY: Yes, and some of those people don't even have a 19 in front of their birth year if you know what I'm saying.

CAVUTO: Is that right?

KENNEDY: Yes, they've done a lot of civil war era.

CAVUTO: I think we have all their Social Security cards. I mean, that was a big -- yes.

KENNEDY: AT&T actually has a vested interest in this because they have done some brand sharing and partnering with RadioShack trying to sell their devices and they might be we are owed that list by virtue of our co-investment and co-branding together.

CAVUTO: But as an update, how do you advice -- you are big on this sort of stuff, word -- either on internet, limit what you share, right?

KENNEDY: I think you should limit what you share. I think you should have one e-mail address for all of your online purchases.

CAVUTO: Wouldn't that have saved Hillary Clinton a lot of trouble?

KENNEDY: And then you should get your own server and have someone named Huma be your wolf dog.

CAVUTO: Isn't that great that she has her own server?

KENNEDY: It's very luxurious. It used to be a 300 foot luxury yachts, and those are just for Russian billionaires that's very boring, so 2004, but your own server, like Martha Stewart used to have her own brand. But she doesn't even have her own server.

CAVUTO: You have a server?

KENNEDY: Yes, exactly.

CAVUTO: Kennedy, thank you very much.

KENNEDY: You got served, Neil. I like you.

CAVUTO: She is on fire. All right, the taxes you leave your heirs will have you wants to save them will trouble, you might want to hear this next Republican out. He is the only one in the Senate not running for president. John Thune is going to tell you how he is on a mission from God.

CAVUTO: Well, raising death tax very much alive and well. To the Republican senator who wants to kill off the estate tax itself before, well, any Democrats including the president get any more bright ideas about hiking it.

South Dakota Senator John Thune joins us with something called the Death Tax Repeal Act of 2015. Senator, always good to see you. What is this about?

SEN. JOHN THUNE (R-SD), SENATE FINANCE COMMITTEE MEMBER: Great to be with you, Neil. Thank you. Well, look, we think that the death tax is punitive. The farmers and ranchers and small business people, family businesses and operations. You want to pass it on to next generation.

The Congressional Budget Office in 2009 said a third of businesses who owe the death tax owe more in taxes than what their assets are worth. So, what typically happens is they have to liquidate the business in order to pay IRS.

It is a tax that is inefficient and it hurts. It hurts jobs and the economy in this country, and we think it is time for it to go. And so we have a bill that would repeal it and end the death tax once and for all.

CAVUTO: Now what kind of support do you have?

THUNE: Well, we have, we got good support obviously among Republicans. We have been reaching out to some Democrats. There are some Democrats in the past, who have expressed support for getting rid of the death tax.

We hope that they will there be some bipartisan support in Congress. Kevin Brady is introducing the bill in the House of Representatives. We are going to hold a news conference tomorrow to talk about why it's important that Congress take the steps that are necessary to do away with this very burdensome, very punitive tax.

CAVUTO: You know, the administration, I am sure you are aware of this, Senator, comes out and says I don't know what Thune is arguing about. The fact of the matter is very few pay this tax because very few really fit the criteria or the means by which to have to pay it. What do you say? I think they say it's closer to 2 percent at that?

THUNE: Right, well, if you look at run-up, Neil, in land values in state like South Dakota over past decade, we have seen land value increase to point now that about a third of the farms in South Dakota are actually over the exemption amount.

So they would be liable to pay the tax. This is a very big issue in farm and ranch country where people are land rich and cash poor, but it also hits a lot of small businesses in this country. Douglas (inaudible) did a study here recently that suggested that ending the death tax would add a million and a half jobs to our economy.

So, we think it is about jobs. It is about growth and you think about how much money people spend to avoid the taxes well, and you know, this isn't something that in our economy we really don't need.

We want to encourage people to pass that family farm or business on to the next generation and getting rid of the death tax would help make that possible.

CAVUTO: As of right now, Senator, you are one of only Republican senators presently not planning to run for president that I know of. So I wonder when you hear and out of your colleagues this idea for simplified tax code and some of these other stuff, they seemed to be very unified. The approach is different. Will that be a Republican rallying cry in 2016 because we're a long way from anything that approaches a simpler tax code?

THUNE: I agree, and it should be a rallying cry. The tax code is way too complicated. It is way too costly to comply with. If we could broaden tax base in this country and lower rates, I think would unleash a period of economic growth unlike anything we've seen in a long time and included in that should be getting rid of the death tax.

You got an administration in Washington right now that very much likes to raise taxes, take from some people and give it to others, and we just think that the best way to get growth in the economy is to get the tax rate down at the lowest level possible.

There were people who are making decisions based up what's best for a return as opposed to tax consequences and so, you know, my hope would be that our candidates in 2016 are out there aggressively talking about their plans to reform tax code to make it more simple, more fair, and lower rates, and focus on economic growth.

CAVUTO: Senator Thune, always a pleasure.

THUNE: Thank you.

CAVUTO: If you decide to run or join your other colleagues, just please let us know, but it's always --

THUNE: You will be first to know, Neil.

CAVUTO: All right. Senator Thune, great seeing you again. Thank you.

THUNE: You too.

CAVUTO: Well, Taylor sure has been swifted, buying up all these porn sites, the skinny on what this rock star is really doing.

CAVUTO: All right, a Fox Biz alert for you, Taylor Swift is buying up all the porn, no, not this porn, dot-porn, grabbing, Taylorswift.porn, what am I thinking? And Taylorswift.adult before the dirty domains go up on sale on the public market this summer.

"STRANGE INHERITANCE" star, Jamie Colby, said nothing strange about it, if she does not do this now, she could facing legal hurdles later. She is not alone. A lot of stars, actresses are trying to do this kind of thing, why?

JAMIE COLBY, FBN HOST, "STRANGE INHERITANCE": It happened to me, someone took my name, and web site, and probably taking Neil Cavuto dot whatever, except porn would be a profitable proposition.

CAVUTO: Although I've run into this myself, but --

COLBY: The things that it takes to be you, Neil.

CAVUTO: And you, you know, we know.

COLBY: It is becoming more difficult to be me, but it's a hell of a lot of fun. I have to tell you that there is no legal case. As you know, I'm the illegal smarty pants and almost every state in America. It is not illegal to take somebody's name and buy a web site with their name with the hope of profiting later.

If you put something on that web site that is disparaging or you make some profit from having that web site, you got to share the profits and you might get sued for saying something wrong.

CAVUTO: So what if she is taking these sites with her name, and they are still being used for porn, can they still be used?

COLBY: No, not. Once she buys them she owns them. She has a proprietary right to whatever goes on them.

CAVUTO: But images of her can pop up on sites where her name is not in it.

COLBY: Well, that she has a right to sue especially if they are used in disparaging way.

CAVUTO: OK, so legally, buying up the names does not shield you from this type of stuff coming up anyway.

COLBY: Well, it is smart of her to buy the name, but I thought question you were posing was if someone else buys the name with her name, is there a suit in ex and of itself there isn't.

I wanted to tell you this could happen to anybody. I went with Rick Ritemoth, our weather dude. He said, you have to come down the street to the deli. You are not going to believe it.

Your face is on an ad for a male healthful product and I said, wait a minute now, we went over there. He saw it hanging over the cash register. You have to come here, your face on an ad for a male health product, it was my picture, I seek legal remedy to get it stopped.

CAVUTO: Did they take it off the deli wall?

COLBY: It is gone. I do not have it any more. If Taylor Swift did not buy the sites, someone else did and they made money, and put something unflattering of Hershey would have a suit, but who whether or not you there was a dot-porn.

CAVUTO: She is a smart lady as of you, how is the show?

COLBY: Great, tonight, if you love "STRANGE INHERITANCE," so many people do. If you love animals, a sanctuary that was left with lions, tigers and bears and that baboon. I met him personally. The way to their heart is through their stomach.

They are rescues, she inherited them, a beautiful story of survival a family that wants to continue a great gesture of taking care of the animal, second one a rancher did not inherit enough land to ranch. He found a surprise of his lifetime. He turned down $5 million for a dinosaur a species that scientists did not know existed.

CAVUTO: Was it a prehistoric?

COLBY: Like this, like this.

CAVUTO: Are you surprised at the success of the show?

COLBY: This is real stuff, this is not reality. This is real families.

CAVUTO: I want to string together your reaction stocks when scary people, you talk to scary people, it seems, find me a window where is the door.

COLBY: Sometimes my chair rolls back.

CAVUTO: Look at the time.

COLBY: That is Dr. Keith Ablow does, I see we're ought of time.

CAVUTO: It's a great show.

COLBY: Thank you.

CAVUTO: She made it because --

COLBY: Tonight at 9 p.m. on Fox Business Network.

CAVUTO: You got it done.

COLBY: But it's a power to prosper and enjoy.

CAVUTO: The idea is to not promote.

COLBY: Excuse me?

CAVUTO: Look at the time. We'll have more right after this.

CAVUTO: And what's the deal with all of this constant Ted Cruz bashing, too brash, too young, too extreme? To a lot of you too much, Dennis in Ohio, "May we point out that Hillary, Biden and Dodd, all the Democratic candidates for president in 2008 told us how inexperienced Obama was, yet they got behind him, when they saw an opportunity to gain power." Such is politics.

Jim emails "Day one of Cruz and the Democrats already spewing hate and lies. And the GOP still have 12 more presidential candidates to come out."

Al emails, "There is no doubt that Cruz is a very bright guy, but I don't see him as having charisma to beat Hillary. He is just not that likable. In addition, I saw his stand on repealing Obamacare, as less than heroic. He knew he was fighting a losing battle yet he was willing to fight until he was the last Republican left standing."

Well, Al, I just say hear him out because he will be part of a very vibrant mix of candidates and ideas that will stimulate and who will stimulate the debate.

Russ and Cathy email, "Hi, Neil, unfortunately, I think you are correct. What a fabulous Cabinet it would be if the Republicans became a team instead of having the blood-letting even if they just played, "Rock, paper, scissors." We would have a great president.

Then Mitt Romney insist that it might be a crowded field, but by convention time, it will be down to one nominee. I disagree. We will not have a nominee by convention time, and that is when Republican seek him out, as maybe a consensus candidate.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: There are a lot of those guys were bummed out when you said you were not going to run. So I'm wondering now, you say never?

MITT ROMNEY, FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: This is not going to happen, I'm sorry, Neil.

CAVUTO: That is never, never.

ROMNEY: It's not going to happen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: I don't know, never, never sounds like maybe to me. Stacy emails, "I just watched your interview with Mr. Romney, it was good, I sure wish he would have made it into office."

Tony in Vermont, "My comment on your Facebook post about Mitt Romney had 600 likes, in first 30 minutes, did I just go viral?" No, you are just hitching along for ride.

Meanwhile, Henry via centurylink.net, "Neil, for a long time, several times, I have written you about criticism about your constant interruptions and also your stupid laugh.

Today, your interview with Governor Mitt Romney was the latest in your annoying actions. So I have designated you as the newest on my list of men a carried for a long time as the least admirable three men in the world, the title you are now on is jerk."

Well, at least, you didn't call me fat. By the way, you got to tell me, who are other two? Buffalo businessman, Karl Paladino weighing in on 2016 and Mitt Romney.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CARL PALADINO (R), FORMER NEW YORK GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE: We need a guy who can create jobs that understands means of creating jobs does not side with 1 percent against the 99 percent. The Republican base, that is there, many of them did not come out for Romney, they done vote. That hurt him.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Tommy in North Carolina, not a fan of Carl's, "Alan Grayson is a very good businessman. That does not mean he is sane. Grayson, Donald Trump, and Carl Paladino should form a club." That would be a wealthy club.

Russ emails, "Good to see Paladino back. Good ideas as always." Finally, this from Jim, "Neil, I see on the news that Hillary has a new e-mail account. Since she isn't using the old one, can we see the server?"

You know, well, I guess, she is not using it. Thanks for watching. "STRANGE INHERITANCE" right now.

Google has struck a $2.1bn deal to buy fitness-tracking pioneer Fitbit, as the two Silicon Valley companies team up to take on Apple’s fast-...

Google has struck a $2.1bn deal to buy fitness-tracking pioneer Fitbit, as the two Silicon Valley companies team up to take on Apple’s fast-growing wearable-tech business.

Fitbit is Google’s biggest acquisition in consumer electronics since it paid $3.2bn for smart home company Nest in 2014. The deal could put Google in the sights of antitrust authorities.

While Google’s cash offer represents a 19 per cent premium to Fitbit’s closing price on Thursday, it prices Fitbit at little more than half of the $4bn valuation at which it went public four years ago.

“Fitbit has been a true pioneer in the industry and has created terrific products, experiences and a vibrant community of users,” said Rick Osterloh, senior vice-president of devices and services at Google.

“We’re looking forward to working with the incredible talent at Fitbit, and bringing together the best hardware, software and AI to build wearables to help even more people around the world.”

The deal, which is conditional on shareholder and regulatory approval, will test Fitbit customers’ willingness to hand over their health and fitness data to Google. The two companies on Friday promised that Fitbit users’ data “will not be used for Google ads” and customers will be able to “review, move or delete their data”.

Nonetheless, some Fitbit owners may be concerned by the prospect of Google owning intimate information about their weight, sleep and menstrual cycles, as well as their heart rate and daily step count. Often these data are coupled with precise location information, which Fitbit uses to map its users’ workouts, as well as links to social networks such as Facebook and Twitter.

Google’s move is a bold one, at a time when regulators in the US and Europe are on high alert for anti-competitive behaviour, data concentration and privacy abuses by big tech companies. Some US presidential candidates have threatened to break up tech companies such as Google, Amazon and Facebook or reverse their previous acquisitions.

David Cicilline, chairman of the antitrust subcommittee in the US House of Representatives, called for antitrust enforcers to investigate the planned merger.

“Google’s proposed acquisition of Fitbit would give the company deep insights into Americans’ most sensitive information—such as their health and location data—threatening to further entrench its market power online,” he said.

“This proposed transaction is a major test of antitrust enforcers’ will and ability to enforce the law and halt anti-competitive concentrations of economic power. It deserves an immediate and thorough investigation.”

Reflecting the heightened risk of intervention, Google has agreed to pay Fitbit a $250m termination fee if it fails to obtain antitrust approval for the deal.

James Park, co-founder and chief executive of Fitbit, said Google was an “ideal partner”. “With Google’s resources and global platform, Fitbit will be able to accelerate innovation in the wearables category, scale faster and make health even more accessible to everyone,” he said.

Google’s offer of $7.35 a share for Fitbit compares with its $20 initial public offering price in June 2015. After closing at a high of $47.49 soon after the IPO, Fitbit’s shares have languished during the past two years as it has attempted to refocus its business away from low-cost fitness trackers towards smartwatches amid intensifying competition from Apple’s Watch.

Google has greatly expanded its hardware portfolio in recent years to include Pixel smartphones, smart speakers, Nest thermostats and security cameras, and various entertainment devices. But it is yet to release its own smartwatch to rival Apple directly.

Nonetheless, Fitbit appears to duplicate many of Google’s existing software platforms. In 2014 Google launched Android Wear, an operating system for smartwatches that was rebranded to Wear OS last year. It also offers a health tracking service, Google Fit.

Despite being used in smartwatches made by the likes of Samsung, Huawei and Fossil, Wear OS has failed to gain real traction in the market. Google said it “remains committed to Wear OS”.

“This is a pure data play,” said Nilesh Chandra, a partner focused on healthcare strategy at PA Consulting, noting tech companies’ broader push into the health industry.

The deal, if approved, is expected to close next year. Qatalyst and Fenwick & West advised Fitbit on the transaction.

Additional reporting by Kiran Stacey in Washington

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y69-4621-JD34-V3PN-00000-00Google talks start over media payments2020-02-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisMARKETING & MEDIAPg. 29Google talks start over media paymentsMax Mason

Facebook and Google must pay publishers for the benefits they receive from high-quality journalism says News Corp Australasia chairman Michael Miller.

His comments come as Google kicks off discussions - demanded by the government - with Australian media companies over how to restrain big tech's bargaining power

This week and next, Google will meet local media companies - including News Corp, Seven West Media and Nine (publisher of The Australian Financial Review) - to try to work out a voluntary code of conduct to govern its business relationships with the local sector before October 31, the deadline set by the competition regulator.

"Without change, many media outlets won't survive because, while their content has helped and is helping the platforms grow their businesses, the returns and compensation for the publishers are inadequate," Mr Miller said.

"The solution is now clear, fair and will be mandated if necessary: big tech should pay publishers from the profits and in the process secure a strong, sustainable media industry and a healthy society."

The meetings follow the government's adopting a recommendation by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to create a code to deal with the imbalance of bargaining power between the global tech giants and the Australian media.

The codes are expected to cover revenue sharing, content monetisation, data sharing and algorithm changes.

In a reply to a letter from ACCC chairman Rod Sims, Google Australia managing director Mel Silva said the US company would look to have one-on-one and cross-company meetings run by a single person, and invited the competition regulator to also sit in.

"Having regard to the diversity of news media organisations in Australia, Google proposes to conduct the code formation process in a manner intended to facilitate a wide range of news media organisations participating in and contributing to the development of the code as is practicable in light of the timeframe," Ms Silva wrote on January 31.

Among subjects expected to be covered, she said, were the "provision of information about Google products and services"; "how data concerning the consumption by users of news content is made available to publishers" and "... the ranking of news content, including notification of actionable changes to the ranking or display of news content". Other discussion points were "the value exchange in relation to news content"; "the presentation of news content"; "dispute resolution and enforcement mechanisms"; "code administration, review and amendment mechanisms"; and "current and potential mechanisms to support the broader news industry".

Ms Silva did not offer any of Google's opinions on the subjects. However, the Google Australia boss previously has accused the ACCC of overlooking the clicks from its search engine that it delivers to Australian media groups.

Media companies have criticised Facebook and Google for not allowing them ways to make money on the platforms so they can fund high-quality content. Mr Miller said the best solution for the industry was for tech companies to enter into arrangements to pay a premium for high-quality journalism.

"Australians need a strong media able to support the journalism that informs a nation, holds the powerful to account, scrutinises how our taxes are spent, exposes corruption, campaigns for good causes and justice, gives a voice to the disadvantaged and celebrates our country's successes," he said.

"The current situation, sadly, is unsustainable - and the government and ACCC have recognised this fact."

Facebook Australia and New Zealand director Mia Garlick said the social media platform was committed to establishing a set of common standards for all news publishers that provided transparency around the distribution of news, protected consumers and encouraged innovation.

"While we have concerns with the underlying analysis for this recommended code, we proposed a version that will address the policy concerns about the role algorithms play in the distribution of digital news," she said.

"The goal here is to foster trust among Australians that news content is treated fairly and avoid distorting the industry by entrenching the market power of one news organisation over another."

Ms Garlick said Facebook would work with the publishers and government on the code and also invest in its publisher partnerships.

Mr Sims has made clear that a code of conduct between the big tech groups such as Facebook and Google and local media companies was the ACCC's most important recommendation from its 18-month digital platforms inquiry.

He said there was a clear imbalance of bargaining power between the tech and media companies, which were unavoidable business partners.

In December, the federal government said if a voluntary code could not be agreed, it would mandate one.

In October, Facebook launched its Facebook News tab in the US alongside News Corp chief executive and long-time critic Robert Thomson. The new tab has 200 "trusted" publishers participating, and some receive between $US1 million ($1.45 million) and $US3 million for sharing news content.

In August, a week after the ACCC's final report was released, Facebook signed short-term deals with Nine, Seven West Media, Network Ten, Sky News, Junkee Media and Pedestrian TV for exclusive news programming for its video service Facebook Watch. The timing of these announcements has drawn scepticism in the media industry as the tech giants continue to argue against a code.

However, Google has softened its stance, with vice-president of news Richard Gingras calling it a sensible idea.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X15-VF81-JBJN-M430-00000-00Google también será investigada por prácticas monopólicas en EEUU2019-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisGoogle también será investigada por prácticas monopólicas en EEUUAmbito Financiero


Las grandes empresas tecnológicas quedaron en los últimos días en la mira de la Justicia de Estados Unidos luego que se anunciara el inicio de investigaciones contra Google y Facebookpor incurrir en supuestas prácticas monopólicas.
La semana pasada se supo que ocho estados del país norteamericano decidieron ir contra la red social, mientras que este lunes 50 fiscales decidieron hacer lo propio con una investigación contra el buscador. Por lo pronto, no se descarta que en los próximos días se conozcan acciones legales contra las otras empresas “big tech” como Amazon o Apple.


Los detalles de la investigación Google para dilucidar si la empresa incurrió en prácticas anticompetitivas fueron anunciados en Washington por el fiscal general del estado de Texas, Ken Paxton, quien liderará el grupo de trabajo multiestatal.

"Es un tema muy importante de nuestra era. Muchos consumidores creen que Internet es libre pero hemos aprendido que no es así. Google es una compañía que domina todos los aspectos de la publicidad", señaló el funcionario.

Según adelantó el fiscal texano, la Justicia investigará si las grandes empresas tecnológicas “han tenido un comportamiento anticompetitivo que sofocó a la competencia, restringió el acceso y perjudicó a los consumidores".

Alphabet, la empresa matriz de Google, tiene un valor de mercado de más de u$s820.000 millones y una enorme influencia en tantos aspectos de Internet: desde las búsquedas hasta la venta de publicidad, los videos, la distribución de aplicaciones y el sistema operativo más popular del mundo, Android.

El anuncio de las investigaciones representa una nueva avanzada regulatoria sobre las cuatro gigantes tecnológicas. El tamaño alcanzado gracias al éxito que cada una de estas compañías tuvo en su rubro comenzó a llamar la atención de fiscales y reguladores, primero en Europa y luego en los Estados Unidos, que cada vez más indagan si las "big tech" usan sus ventajas para perjudicar a la competencia y expandir su dominio.

Google adelantó el último viernes que había recibido una demanda de investigación civil por parte del Departamento de Justicia de los Estados Unidos. "Esperamos recibir en el futuro demandas de investigación similares de los fiscales generales estatales. Continuamos cooperando con el Departamento (de Justicia), los reguladores federales y estatales en los Estados Unidos y otros reguladores en todo el mundo", informó la empresa.

Vale mencionar que la Unión Europea está detrás de Google desde hace tiempo impulsando varias investigaciones. En marzo pasado, la empresa recibió una multa de casi u$s1.700 millones por parte de Europa por abusar del dominio que mantiene en el mercado de la publicidad online.

urn:contentItem:5X1C-9BB1-DYRV-43TB-00000-00Google targeted in antitrust probe2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisAPg. A005Google targeted in antitrust probeRachel Lerman and Marcy Gordon

1) District of Columbia Attorney General Karl Racine, left, and Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton speak during the launch of an antitrust investigation into large tech companies outside of the U.S. Supreme Court in Washington, D.C. on Monday. PHOTO: Mandel Ngan/Getty Images

WASHINGTON - Fifty U.S. states and territories, led by Texas, announced an investigation into Google's "potential monopolistic behavior." The Monday announcement closely followed one from a separate group of states Friday that disclosed an investigation into Facebook's market dominance. The two probes widen the antitrust scrutiny of big tech companies beyond sweeping federal and congressional investigations and enforcement action by European regulators. Nebraska attorney general Doug Peterson, a Republican, said at a press conference held in Washington that 50 attorneys general joining together sends a "strong message to Google."

California and Alabama are not part of the investigation, although it does include the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. Tara Gallegos, a spokeswoman for California Attorney General Xavier Becerra, declined to confirm or deny any state investigation and would not comment on the announcement by the other states. Mike Lewis, a spokesman for Alabama Attorney General Steve Marshall, also said the state's legal team had no comment on the probe. The news conference featured a dozen Republican attorneys general plus the Democratic attorney general of Washington, D.C. Google's parent company, Alphabet, has a market value of more than $820 billion and controls so many facets of the internet that it's fairly impossible to surf the web for long without running into at least one of its services. Google's dominance in online search and advertising enables it to target millions of consumers for their personal data. Google expects the state authorities will ask the company about past similar investigations in the U.S. and internationally, senior vice president of global affairs Kent Walker wrote in a blog post Friday. Critics often point to Google's 2007 acquisition of online advertising company DoubleClick as pivotal to its advertising dominance. Europe's antitrust regulators slapped Google with a $1.7 billion fine in March for unfairly inserting exclusivity clauses into contracts with advertisers, disadvantaging rivals in the online ad business. One outcome antitrust regulators might explore is forcing Google to spin off search as a separate company, experts say. Regulators also could focus on areas such as Google's popular video site YouTube, an acquisition Google scored in 2006. Joining Paxton, a Republican, in the investigation are the attorneys general of almost all U.S. states and the District of Columbia. Google has long argued that although its businesses are large, they are useful and beneficial to consumers. "Google is one of America's top spenders on research and development, making investments that spur innovation," Walker wrote. "Things that were science fiction a few years ago are now free for everyone - translating any language instantaneously, learning about objects by pointing your phone, getting an answer to pretty much any question you might have." But federal and state regulators and policymakers are growing more concerned not just with the company's impact on ordinary internet users, but also on smaller companies striving to compete in Google's markets. "On the one hand, you could just say, 'well Google is dominant because they're good,'" said Jen King, the director of privacy at Stanford's Center for Internet and Society. "But at the same time, it's created an ecosystem where people's whole internet experience is mediated through Google's home page and Google's other products." Experts believe the probe could focus on at least one of three areas that have caught regulators' eyes. A good first place to look might be online advertising. Google will control 31.1% of global digital ad dollars in 2019, according to eMarketer estimates, crushing a distant second-place Facebook. And many smaller advertisers have argued that Google has such a stranglehold on the market that it becomes a system of whatever Google says, goes - because the alternative could be not reaching customers. "There's definitely concern on the part of the advertisers themselves that Google wields way too much power in setting rates and favoring their own services over others," King said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X17-4SC1-JDK3-9096-00000-00Google target of antitrust investigation led by 50 U.S. states and territories2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:27ZLexisNexisWORLDGoogle target of antitrust investigation led by 50 U.S. states and territories

Attorneys general for 50 U.S. states and territories on Monday officially announced an antitrust investigation of Google, embarking on a wide-ranging review of a tech giant that Democrats and Republicans said may threaten competition, consumers and the continued growth of the web.

Appearing on the steps of the Supreme Court, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton charged that Google "dominates all aspects of advertising on the Internet and searching on the Internet," though he cautioned that despite his criticism the states had launched an investigation for now and not a lawsuit.

Paxton said the probe's initial focus is online advertising. Google is expected to rake in more than $48 billion in U.S. digital ad revenue this year, far outperforming its peers, while capturing 75 per cent of all spending on U.S. search ads, according to eMarketer.

"They dominate the buyer side, the seller side, the auction side and the video side with YouTube," he said during a news conference alongside officials from 11 states and the District of Columbia.

Karl Racine, District of Columbia attorney general, center left, speaks as Ken Paxton, Texas attorney general, center right, listens during a news conference outside the Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Monday, Sept. 9, 2019.

Some of those attorneys general appeared to raise additional complaints about Google, ranging from the way the company processes and ranks search results to the extent to which it may not fully protect users' personal information. Their early rebukes raised the stakes for Google, threatening top-to-bottom scrutiny of its sprawling business beyond just ads. Paxton promised the probe would go wherever the facts lead.

"There's nothing wrong with being a dominant player when it's done fairly," said Sean Reyes, the Republican attorney general of Utah. He said there is a "presumption" of innocence in such an investigation but still said there is a "pervasiveness" to complaints about Google's business practices.

Jeff Landry, a Republican from Louisiana, added: "We're here because there's an absolutely existential threat to our virtual marketplace."

Google declined to comment, pointing to its previous statements saying it will work with state officials.

The probe marks the latest regulatory headache for Google and the rest of Silicon Valley, which have faced growing criticism - and widening state and federal scrutiny - into whether they've grown too big and powerful, undermining rivals and resulting in costlier or worse service for web users. The Washington Post first reported the states' plans for a Google probe last week.

For Google, though, the states' investigation comes more than six years after federal watchdogs wrapped up an antitrust investigation into its search and advertising practices and opted against bringing major penalties against the company, including breaking it up. Regulators around the world, meanwhile, have been more skeptical of Google: The European Union has issued the company $9 billion in competition-related fines over the past three years.

The states' investigation is led by Texas' Paxton and seven other attorneys general, four Democrats and four Republicans in total. Every state except Alabama and California, the home of Silicon Valley, so far has signed onto the bipartisan effort, as have Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia. A spokeswoman for California's attorney general did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Huawei faces loss of some Google services after US ban( https://nationalpost.com/news/world/google-says-services-on-huawei-phone-still-will-function )

Google tends to push stories for left-leaning readers, study shows( https://nationalpost.com/news/world/google-tends-to-push-stories-for-left-leaning-readers-study-shows )

Lateness of changes to federal election bill behind decision to ban Canadian political advertising, Google says( https://nationalpost.com/news/politics/lateness-of-changes-to-federal-election-bill-behind-decision-to-ban-canadian-political-advertising-google-says )

Already, state officials have sent official legal demands for documents to the tech giant related to the investigation of online ads, Paxton told reporters.

Ashley Moody, the Republican attorney general of Florida, said the states' Google probe starts with the company's vast data stores. "Google monitors our online behavior, and captures data on every one of us as we navigate the internet," she said. "This investigation will initially focus on capture of that information and whether Google embedded itself on every level of the online market [for] ad sales to monopolize this industry."

Leslie Rutledge, a Republican attorney general from Arkansas, described Google as an "online search engine juggernaut," raising her concern that searches for businesses, including doctors, are colored by the way the tech giant's algorithms and advertising systems work.

"I want the best advice, from the best doctors - not the doctor, not the clinic who can spend the most on advertising," she said.

The states' investigation arrives as the Department of Justice and FTC also are scrutinizing Big Tech, and DOJ has taken early interest in Google. The agency issued its first legal demand for records at the end of August, according to a securities filing Google made Friday.

Another group of 11 state attorneys general - led by New York's Letitia James - has begun their own probe against Facebook, exploring whether it violates competition laws and mishandles consumers' personal information.

Some state leaders said they are working closely with their federal counterparts as these investigations unfold. But Karl Racine, the Democratic attorney general for Washington, D.C., and a participant in both the Facebook and Google probes, said he and his peers wouldn't hesitate to forge ahead if Washington once again opts against taking action against the tech giants.

"The state attorneys general, they are an independent bunch, and they can be quite tenacious," he said . "So I'm very confident that this bipartisan group is going to be led by the facts, and not be swayed by any conclusion, that may fall short, if you will, if it's inconsistent with our facts, on the [federal] side." !@COPYRIGHT=© 2019 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

urn:contentItem:5Y36-CRY1-JBKR-G4XG-00000-00Google target of antitrust investigation led by 50 U.S. states and territories2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:27ZLexisNexisWORLDGoogle target of antitrust investigation led by 50 U.S. states and territories

Attorneys general for 50 U.S. states and territories on Monday officially announced an antitrust investigation of Google, embarking on a wide-ranging review of a tech giant that Democrats and Republicans said may threaten competition, consumers and the continued growth of the web.

Appearing on the steps of the Supreme Court, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton charged that Google "dominates all aspects of advertising on the Internet and searching on the Internet," though he cautioned that despite his criticism the states had launched an investigation for now and not a lawsuit.

Paxton said the probe's initial focus is online advertising. Google is expected to rake in more than $48 billion in U.S. digital ad revenue this year, far outperforming its peers, while capturing 75 per cent of all spending on U.S. search ads, according to eMarketer.

"They dominate the buyer side, the seller side, the auction side and the video side with YouTube," he said during a news conference alongside officials from 11 states and the District of Columbia.

Karl Racine, District of Columbia attorney general, center left, speaks as Ken Paxton, Texas attorney general, center right, listens during a news conference outside the Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Monday, Sept. 9, 2019.

Some of those attorneys general appeared to raise additional complaints about Google, ranging from the way the company processes and ranks search results to the extent to which it may not fully protect users' personal information. Their early rebukes raised the stakes for Google, threatening top-to-bottom scrutiny of its sprawling business beyond just ads. Paxton promised the probe would go wherever the facts lead.

"There's nothing wrong with being a dominant player when it's done fairly," said Sean Reyes, the Republican attorney general of Utah. He said there is a "presumption" of innocence in such an investigation but still said there is a "pervasiveness" to complaints about Google's business practices.

Jeff Landry, a Republican from Louisiana, added: "We're here because there's an absolutely existential threat to our virtual marketplace."

Google declined to comment, pointing to its previous statements saying it will work with state officials.

The probe marks the latest regulatory headache for Google and the rest of Silicon Valley, which have faced growing criticism - and widening state and federal scrutiny - into whether they've grown too big and powerful, undermining rivals and resulting in costlier or worse service for web users. The Washington Post first reported the states' plans for a Google probe last week.

For Google, though, the states' investigation comes more than six years after federal watchdogs wrapped up an antitrust investigation into its search and advertising practices and opted against bringing major penalties against the company, including breaking it up. Regulators around the world, meanwhile, have been more skeptical of Google: The European Union has issued the company $9 billion in competition-related fines over the past three years.

The states' investigation is led by Texas' Paxton and seven other attorneys general, four Democrats and four Republicans in total. Every state except Alabama and California, the home of Silicon Valley, so far has signed onto the bipartisan effort, as have Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia. A spokeswoman for California's attorney general did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Ashley Moody, the Republican attorney general of Florida, said the states' Google probe starts with the company's vast data stores. "Google monitors our online behavior, and captures data on every one of us as we navigate the internet," she said. "This investigation will initially focus on capture of that information and whether Google embedded itself on every level of the online market [for] ad sales to monopolize this industry."

Leslie Rutledge, a Republican attorney general from Arkansas, described Google as an "online search engine juggernaut," raising her concern that searches for businesses, including doctors, are colored by the way the tech giant's algorithms and advertising systems work.

"I want the best advice, from the best doctors - not the doctor, not the clinic who can spend the most on advertising," she said.

The states' investigation arrives as the Department of Justice and FTC also are scrutinizing Big Tech, and DOJ has taken early interest in Google. The agency issued its first legal demand for records at the end of August, according to a securities filing Google made Friday.

Another group of 11 state attorneys general - led by New York's Letitia James - has begun their own probe against Facebook, exploring whether it violates competition laws and mishandles consumers' personal information.

Some state leaders said they are working closely with their federal counterparts as these investigations unfold. But Karl Racine, the Democratic attorney general for Washington, D.C., and a participant in both the Facebook and Google probes, said he and his peers wouldn't hesitate to forge ahead if Washington once again opts against taking action against the tech giants.

urn:contentItem:5X10-PJ01-JBYT-H18K-00000-00Google target of new US antitrust probe by state attorneys general2019-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisGoogle target of new US antitrust probe by state attorneys generalNew Delhi, 2019-09-09 15:31:19

September 09 -- More than 30 U.S. state attorneys general are readying an investigation into Alphabet Inc's Google for potential antitrust violations, a source knowledgeable about the probe said on Tuesday. Texas leads the group of 30-plus attorneys general, which plans to announce the probe on Sept. 9, the source said. Google said that it was cooperating with the state officials. "We continue to work constructively with regulators, including attorneys general, in answering questions about our business and the dynamic technology sector," Google representative Jose Castaneda said. The probe is focused on the intersection of privacy and antitrust, according to the source, who did not elaborate. Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, filed comments along with 42 other state officials in June that urged the Federal Trade Commission to focus on privacy and data collection in investigating potential violations of antitrust law. In the comment, the state officials argued that the big tech firms have so much user data that it is hard for newcomers to compete. Another Texas official, Assistant Attorney General Jeff Mateer, alleged in an FTC hearing in June that Google and other big tech companies were misleading in representing themselves as neutral, citing Google's balking at carrying an ad about "what it means to be an American, the Texas attorney general's office said in a statement in June. Google eventually relented on the ad, the statement said. 


The tech giants, among the richest and most powerful companies in the world, are facing increasing antitrust scrutiny from Congress, federal agencies and now state attorneys general. The Justice Department said in July that it was opening a broad investigation of major digital technology firms, focusing on whether they engage in anticompetitive practices. The investigation is believed to be aimed at Google, Amazon.com Inc and Facebook Inc , and potentially Apple Inc . Separately, the Federal Trade Commission, which also enforces antitrust law, is also probing Amazon and Facebook to determine if they abused their massive market power in retail and social media, respectively. The Washington Post was the first to report the development on Tuesday.
