Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X0C-DJ41-JD88-353K-00000-00Google target of new U.S. antitrust probe by state attorneys general2019-09-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisGoogle target of new U.S. antitrust probe by state attorneys general

More than 30 U.S. state attorneys general are readying an investigation into Alphabet Incs Google for potential antitrust violations, a source knowledgeable about the probe said on Tuesday.

Texas leads the group of 30-plus attorneys general, which plans to announce the probe on Sept. 9, the source said.

Google said that it was cooperating with the state officials.

We continue to work constructively with regulators, including attorneys general, in answering questions about our business and the dynamic technology sector, Google representative Jose Castaneda said.

The probe is focused on the intersection of privacy and antitrust, according to the source, who did not elaborate.

Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, filed comments along with 42 other state officials in June that urged the Federal Trade Commission to focus on privacy and data collection in investigating potential violations of antitrust law.

In the comment, the state officials argued that the big tech firms have so much user data that it is hard for newcomers to compete.

Another Texas official, Assistant Attorney General Jeff Mateer, alleged in an FTC hearing in June that Google and other big tech companies were misleading in representing themselves as neutral, citing Googles balking at carrying an ad about what it means to be an American, the Texas attorney generals office said in a statement in June. Google eventually relented on the ad, the statement said.

The tech giants, among the richest and most powerful companies in the world, are facing increasing antitrust scrutiny from Congress, federal agencies and now state attorneys general.

The Justice Department said in July that it was opening a broad investigation of major digital technology firms, focusing on whether they engage in anticompetitive practices. The investigation is believed to be aimed at Google, Amazon.com Inc and Facebook Inc, and potentially Apple Inc.

Separately, the Federal Trade Commission, which also enforces antitrust law, is also probing Amazon and Facebook to determine if they abused their massive market power in retail and social media, respectively.

The Washington Post was the first to report the development on Tuesday.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XF4-02J1-JBSN-10M5-00000-00Google Targets Fitbit's Wearables, Healthcare Data2019-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:27ZLexisNexisGoogle Targets Fitbit's Wearables, Healthcare Databy Chris Nolter

Alphabet Inc.'s (GOOGL) Google is getting serious about wearables and healthcare data with the $2.1 billion purchase of Fitbit Inc. (FIT), announced Friday, Nov. 1.

"Google is the best match for Fitbit because of the data," D.A. Davidson & Co. analyst Tom Forte said of the trove of health care information that Fitbit collects from its smart watches and fitness trackers.

"Google is seeing what Apple is doing in the health care space, including with data," he added. "Especially when you consider the huge cash position that Fitbit has, this is a very cheap acquisition for Google."

The transaction was announced as federal and state investigators https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/20001116/index.dl|probeGoogle to examine allegations of anti-competitive conduct and questions of whether its strategy of acquiring promising startups that present competitive threats should face more antitrust scrutiny.

"This is a real test," Forte said. Will regulators view the deal as a relatively small acquisition by Google in terms of valuation, especially when netting out the $565 million in cash on Fitbit's books at the end of the second quarter? Or will they review it as a significant acquisition of customer data, including sensitive information about users' health?

"The regulatory challenge across the globe for the four horsemen of big tech -- Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google -- is how do all governments, not just the U.S. government, grapple with those four companies having so much influence on consumer behavior and, in this case, Google acquiring Fitbit [and its] just tremendous healthcare data."

Google would pay $7.35 per share for Fitbit, if it receives regulatory approvals and completes other conditions for closing.

Fitbit stock rose 15% to $7.11 per share on Friday, and had traded under $4 per share earlier in October before reports of Google's interest surfaced.

Alphabet gained 0.4% to $1,263.60 on Friday.

Fitbit has been losing ground in wearables in recent years to Apple and Samsung, Neil Mawston of Strategy Analytics wrote in an email to The Deal.

Shipments of Fitbit's smartwatches fell from 1.3 million in the second quarter of 2018 to 1.2 million in the  second quarter of 2019, according to Strategy Analytics. Meanwhile, Samsung overtook the company as the No. 2 smartwatch vendor, with a 15.9% market share compared to Fitbit's 9.8%.

Google has had its own issues in wearables. Its Wear OS smartwatch operating system is much less successful than Android in smartphones, Strategy Analytics' Mawston said, noting that Google may want Fitbit s expertise to boost its rumored Pixel wearables product line in 2020.

With the purchase of Fitbit, the company is upping the stakes since making the $40 million https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/14838683/index.dl|purchase of smartwatch intellectual property from Fossil Group Inc. (FOSL), announced in January.

The exit may be bittersweet for long-term shareholders of Fitbit, which was worth $4.1 billion after its 2015 IPO.

"Selling to Google is success, but this is definitely not what investors envisioned when it first came public," Forte said. "But credit to management that they were smart enough to realize that, the way things panned out, this is a successful outcome."

George Boutros at Qatalyst Partners LP advised Fitbit, which received counsel from a team at Fenwick & West LLP led by Doug Cogen.

Paul Haigney at Lazard advised Google.

Aaron Meyers and Glenn McGrory of Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton LLP provided counsel to Google.

Ethan Klingsberg, Google s longtime outside corporate counsel who moved from Cleary to Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer LLP last week, also advised the buyer, according to a source familiar with the situation.

--David Hatch and David Marcus contributed to this report

DEAL SIZE

$ 1-10 Billion

urn:contentItem:5N17-HB41-F0J6-J2Y6-00000-00Google tax doesn't threaten tech giant;Exclusive2017-03-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisMARKETING & MEDIAPg. 29Googletax doesn't threaten tech giantExclusiveNeil Chenoweth

Googleis facing a watershed in thenext four months over its tax arrangements in Australia - the most visible flashpointinthe dispute thathas beenbuilding between the tax office and big tech companies for more than three years. The first key date is at the end of April, when GoogleAustralia usually files its results for calendar 2016. This is the first year for Australia's Multinational Anti-Avoidance Law (MAAL), also known as the GoogleTax, which came into operation on January 1 last year. The second date is in June, when tax commissioner Chris Jordan has forecast tax assessments totalling $2 billion will be issued to seven global businesses. Almost all of these cases grew out of an international collaboration that Mr Carmody proposed at a meeting of the OECD's Forum on Tax Administration (FTA)inOctober 2013, to targetbig tech companies.

The collaboration became the model to investigate the Panama Papers files last year. While the tech companies have never been identified, they are believed to include Apple and Google. GoogleAustralia appeared to refer to the tax audit in its 2015 annual report release last April: ''From time to time the company is subject to legal claims or reviews by regulatory authorities in the normal course of business. ''At 31 December 2015, the directors do not believe the status of any of these claims or reviews results in a significant contingent liability.'' In the same report GoogleAustralia noted in response to MAAL: ''Effective 1 January 2016, GoogleAustralia Pty Ltd restructured its business such that it will recognise revenue from the marketing and selling of certain services and products to Australianbased customers.'' While GoogleAustralia reported $502 million in revenue in 2015, this was dwarfedby the $2 billioninGoogle ad sales thatis paid directly to its Singapore arm from Australian customers, on which it pays $5 million Singaporean tax (at least, it was said to be $2 billion two years go but Google's non-US sales are up 30 per cent since then). MAAL targets some of this Singapore income. GoogleAustralia noted: ''Given the preliminary stage of the restructure, we are unable to reliably estimate the financial effect of this chance as at the date of signing the financial report.'' Google's parent company Alphabet Inc has already filed its 2016 annual report and Australia didn't get a mention. In the previous two years it had cited Australian currency changes as affecting the earnings,but notthis year. In summary then, Googleexpects to pay zero on the current tax audit, and when it comes to paying MAAL it doesn't see a significant effect. GoogleAustralia remains a quirky company. From 2010 to 2015 it lifted revenue from $151 million to $502 million, but its pre-tax earnings only rose from a $2 million loss toa$50 million profit. Where has all that revenue gone? The biggest rise in costs has been employee benefits, which rose by $124 million to $235 million in the five years to 2015 - largely from the higher headcount, Googlesays. Of that cost, a quarter was sharebased payments to employees. In return for issuing the performance rightsonAlphabet shares toAustralian employees, GoogleAustralia paid its parent $60 million. ThispaymenttoAlphabetmore than halved its Australian taxable income. In 2015, the world's largest media/ advertising company spent $56 million on ''advertising and promotional expense''. Was that payments to other Googlearms? A spokesman said the $56 million ''related to marketing of Googleservices to Australian customers; it includes a number [of] marketing channels''. How much of the marketing and bonuses and share-based payments related to Googlead revenue that ended up in Singapore is unclear. That seems to be one of the issues with the tax audi

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5N19-1JP1-JBJ7-N533-00000-00Google tax doesn't threaten the tech giant2017-03-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisGoogle tax doesn't threaten the tech giantNeil Chenoweth

Google is playing it cool on the new tax and the audit

Google is facing a watershed in the next four months over its tax arrangements in Australia - the most visible flashpoint in the dispute that has been building between the tax office and big tech companies for more than three years.

The first key date is at the end of April, when Google Australia usually files its results for calendar 2016.

This is the first year for Australia's Multinational Anti-Avoidance Law (MAAL), also known as the Google Tax, which came into operation on January 1 last year.

The second date is in June, when tax commissioner Chris Jordan has forecast tax assessments totaling $2 billion will be issued to seven global businesses.

Almost all of these cases grew out of an international collaboration that Mr Carmody proposed at a meeting of the OECD's Forum on Tax Administration (FTA) in October 2013, to target big tech companies.

The collaboration became the model to investigate the Panama Papers files last year.

While the tech companies have never been identified, they are believed to include Apple and Google.

Google Australia appeared to refer to the tax audit in its 2015 annual report release last April: "From time to time the company is subject to legal claims or reviews by regulatory authorities in the normal course of business.

"At 31 December 2015, the directors do not believe the status of any of these claims or reviews results in a significant contingent liability."

In the same report Google Australia noted in response to MAAL: "Effective 1 January 2016, Google Australia Pty Ltd restructured its business such that it will recognise revenue from the marketing and selling of certain services and products to Australian-based customers."

While Google Australia reported $502 million in revenue in 2015, this was dwarfed by the $2 billion in Google ad sales that is paid directly to its Singapore arm from Australian customers, on which it pays $5 million Singaporean tax (at least, it was said to be $2 billion two years go, but Google's non-US sales are up 30 per cent since then).

MAAL targets some of this Singapore income.

Google Australia noted: "Given the preliminary stage of the restructure, we are unable to reliably estimate the financial effect of this chance as at the date of signing the financial report."

Google's parent company Alphabet Inc has already filed its 2016 annual report, and Australia didn't get a mention. In the previous two years it had cited Australian currency changes as affecting the earnings, but not this year.

In summary then, Google expects to pay zero on the current tax audit, and when it comes to paying MAAL it doesn't see a significant effect.

Google Australia remains a quirky company. From 2010 to 2015 it lifted revenue from $151 million to $502 million, but its pre-tax earnings only rose from a $2 million loss to a $50 million profit.

Where has all that revenue gone?

The biggest rise in costs has been employee benefits, which rose by $124 million to $235 million in the five years to 2015 - largely from the higher headcount, Google says.

Of that cost, a quarter was share-based payments to employees. In return for issuing the performance rights on Alphabet shares to Australian employees, Google Australia paid its parent $60 million.

This payment to Alphabet more than halved its Australian taxable income.

In 2015, the world's largest media/advertising company spent $56 million on "advertising and promotional expense".

Was that payments to other Google arms?

A spokesman said the $56 million "related to marketing of Google services to Australian customers; it includes a number [of] marketing channels".

How much of the marketing and bonuses and share-based payments related to Google ad revenue that ended up in Singapore is unclear. That seems to be one of the issues with the tax audit.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:4SYD-2RC0-TWD4-11HN-00000-00Google tells Bell to stop 'throttling' Web users; 'Violation Of Law'2008-07-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:27ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. FP1Googletells Bell to stop 'throttling' Web users; 'Violation Of Law'Barbara ShecterFinancial Post

Internet heavyweight Google Inc.has waded into a fight with Bell Canada, saying the telecommunications company should be "prohibited" from the practice of curtailing peer-to-peer Internet use to manage capacity on its network.

"Network management does not include Canadian carriers blocking or degrading lawful applications that consumers wish to use," Google says.

Googlemakes its claims in a document made public by the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission.

"Providers of broadband Internet access services, including Bell, should be prohibited from throttling lawful applications," Google says.

Google, a search engine giant that has also taken a major bite out of online video and social networking with the purchase of YouTube, calls the practice of throttling or managing Internet usage "a violation of Canadian telecommunications law, which forbids unfair discrimination."

Executives at Bell and other Internet service providers such as Rogers Communications Inc.say they have no choice but to slow down the heaviest users of uploading and downloading services at peak times in order to ensure everyone has access to their networks.

But Googleaccuses Bell of controlling Internet traffic instead of expanding its network and deploying technology to deal with congestion. The issue "goes to the heart of the Internet and how it acts as an extraordinary platform for innovation and fair competition," the Googledocument says.

"The fight is just beginning and the battle lines are being drawn now that we have the world's top Internet brand taking a side," said Kaan Yigit of telecom consultancy Solutions Research Group Inc.

"Google's involvement immediately brings a new dimension to this and legitimizes the issue -- it's not just ISPs [such as Bell] versus a number of underfunded consumer groups or independents, but ISPs versus content providers."

Iain Grant, managing director of telecom consultant The Seaboard Group, said Googleentering the fray illustrates a sharp difference of opinion among large tech firms.

"Google's entire business model is based on the idea of a boundless Internet. … They are the ranchers of the 19th-century American West [and] their cows should be free to graze wherever," he said.

By contrast, big tech companies such as Cisco Systems Inc. do not oppose traffic throttling, Mr. Grant said. "Cisco knows that there are real costs involved in meeting traffic demands."

The throttling issue first landed at the feet of the Canada's telecommunications regulator in April, when a group of independent Internet service providers who run their services on the big networks filed a complaint.

The dust-up that is now in front of the CRTC is somewhat limited, but it should prompt a wider look at telecommunications laws in Canada, said Alan Sawyer, a media strategist at Two Solitudes Consulting.

"A formal net neutrality hearing by the commission is much needed and, if existing laws are not in keeping with the realities of the 21st century, they need to be changed," he said.

"The reality is that responsible network management may very well, at times, include traffic prioritization," Mr. Sawyer said. "Network capacity is never infinite and like any resource it must be managed -- but it must be managed in a fair and responsible manner that best serves the needs of the majority of consumers."

urn:contentItem:5XH4-0MN1-F03R-N3RJ-00000-00Google Throws Curveball, Plans To Offer Online Checking Accounts In 20202019-11-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisGoogle Throws Curveball, Plans To Offer Online Checking Accounts In 2020Shane McGlaun

Nov 14, 2019( Hot Hardware: http://hothardware.com Delivered by Newstex) Google is set to make a big push in the consumer banking market with a project code-named Cache. The project will see the search giant offer checking accounts to consumers in the U.S. in conjunction with Citigroup and the Stanford Federal Credit Union.

A Google spokesman says that the search giant is exploring how to partner with banks and credit unions in the States.The smart checking accounts would be offered via Google Pay[1], and customers at the partner banks would be able to benefit from useful checking insights and budgeting tools. By partnering with the banks, the account holders would be able to keep their money in an FDIC or NCUA-insured account.The Google[2] spokesman noted that the company looked forward to sharing more details in the coming months, and that it has no intention of selling customer data. A Google executive has stated that if the search giant can help people "do more stuff in a digital way online," that it is good for Google and the internet in general.Google is certainly not the first major tech firm to look to step into banking and financial industries. Facebook had several credit card companies and banks on board with Libra before all its partners pulled out[3]. And Apple recently launched its Apple Card, which is a digital-centric credit card that further ties customers into its walled garden. Google plans to brand its checking accounts with the financial institution names, not its own. Google has offered no hard details on how its services will benefit the users, but more is expected closer to launch.At least one U.S. senator is calling for regulations to be put in place for big tech companies entering into new fields. Sen Mark Warner says that he is concerned about the tech firms entering the new fields ahead of regulations being in place because once they enter the new field, it will be "virtually impossible" to get them out. [ 1]: https://hothardware.com/tags/google-pay [ 2]:   https://hothardware.com/tags/google [ 3]:   https://hothardware.com/news/libra-loses-backers

urn:contentItem:5XDP-RJM1-DY7P-T0D7-00000-00Google to acquire wearable-tech maker Fitbit for $2.1B2019-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisMARKETSPg. 1Google to acquire wearable-tech maker Fitbit for $2.1BJean Garcia

The stock has recovered since news broke that Google might swoop in to bid, but is still far below Fitbit's $20 per-share price in the company's 2015 initial public offering.

Osterloh added, "Over the years, Google has made progress with partners in this space with Wear OS and Google Fit, but we see an opportunity to invest even more in Wear OS as well as introduce Made by Google wearable devices into the market".

Fitbit's fitness trackers monitor users' daily steps, calories burned and distance traveled. In any case, Wear OS works on both Android and iOS devices too, albeit with much tighter integration on the former.

The company's shares have gained more than 40% since Reuters reported on Monday that Google had made an offer for the maker of the popular colorful fitness trackers.

The deal isn't expected to close until 2020, assuming regulatory and stockholder approval, so I wouldn't expect any Google-branded Fitbit devices just yet.

Antitrust regulators have been "slow to the game" when it comes to looking at how data plays into fortifying monopoly power, said Sally Hubbard, the director of enforcement strategy at Open Markets Institute, which has advocated for tougher competition enforcement against tech giants. "Fitbit will continue to put users in control of their data and will remain transparent about the data it collects and why".

Curry leads Warriors to first win, 134-123 over Pelicans Associated Press

Draymond Green made his 23rd career triple-double and led the Golden State Warriors to the first victory of the season (1-2). Curry said he and Green are accepting more complicated roles on a team that is trying to assimilate an infusion of youth.

But analysts said the health data was key the deal.

Buying Fitbit would give Google a new platform along with access to the company's more than 27 million active users.

The deal will expand Google's range of consumer products, which already includes smartphones, headphones, smart speakers and laptops. "Google knows politicians and regulators have the company in their sights with another battle now on the horizon in this big tech vs beltway theme".

For Fitbit, it's a noble exit after putting up a decent fight in the years since the launch of Apple's smartwatch. With Google's resources and global platform, Fitbit will be able to accelerate innovation in the wearables category, scale faster, and make health even more accessible to everyone. Fitbit has tons of experience pumping out hardware for millions of people.

Following recent rumors, it's now official: Google's parent company Alphabet is buying Fitbit.

By next year, the health data Fitbit has on its users today will become Google's data - a valuable acquisition for Google, undoubtedly, but one that I predict could make consumers uncomfortable.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5JRW-9PM1-JBTY-W20R-00000-00Google to ban payday loan ads;Tech giant is drawing attention to lending epidemic that plagues mainly low-income Canadians2016-05-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. S9Google to ban payday loan adsTech giant is drawing attention to lending epidemic that plagues mainly low-income Canadians

Google announced Wednesday that it will ban all payday loan ads from its site, bowing to concerns by advocates who say the lending practice exploits the poor and vulnerable by offering them immediate cash that must be paid back under sky-high interest rates.

The decision is the first time Google has announced a global ban on ads for a category of financial products. To this point, the search giant has prohibited ads for largely illicit activities such as selling guns, explosives and drugs, and limited those that are sexually explicit or graphic in nature, for example.

Critics of payday lenders say they hope the move by Google and other tech companies might undercut the business which finds huge numbers of willing customers on the Internet.

In Canada, anti-poverty group ACORN, which is campaigning against predatory lending, celebrated that the influential tech giant is drawing attention to a problem that plagues mainly low-income Canadians, the Star's Sunny Freeman reports.

"Sometimes I think people go to these places just out of desperation so quickly that they don't even think about it and doing it online makes it even easier for people," said spokeswoman Donna Borden.

"A lot of people that we talk to say 'I should have waited and thought it out.'"

However, Borden said she was disappointed that a further Google U.S. ban on ads for loans with an annual interest rate of 36 per cent or higher does not apply in Canada, where high-interest instalment loans, are largely unregulated.

Banning payday loan ads from Google is an encouraging start in reducing harm to consumers who often fall prey to payday loan companies, usually those who are underbanked, heavily debt-burdened and financially vulnerable, said Jeffrey Schwartz, executive director, Consolidated Credit Counseling Services of Canada.

"Payday loans can create a harmful cycle of debt, especially for those who are the most vulnerable in society. This decision will help to protect susceptible consumers online."

The Canadian Payday Loan Association, which represents licensed payday lenders, did not respond to requests for comment.

Still, Google's move shows the willingness of big tech companies to weigh in on critical policy issues - and exert their power as the gateways for the internet. Facebook also does not display ads for payday loans. But others, such as Yahoo, still do.

Consumers will still be able to find payday lenders from a Google search. But the ads that appear on the top and right-hand side of a search results page will not show marketing from the payday lending industry beginning on July 13.

"We'll continue to review the effectiveness of this policy, but our hope is that fewer people will be exposed to misleading or harmful products," Google global product policy director David Graff said in a blog post about the change.

Washington regulators, as well as a handful of states, have been trying to limit the activities of payday lenders by capping how much they can charge consumers in an interest rate.

But the decisions by tech giants Facebook and Google - the two biggest websites on the planet - might have as much impact as any single regulation in restricting access to payday lenders.

Industry officials, speaking generally of advertising restrictions placed on payday lenders, called the policies "discriminatory," adding that some consumers may need access to the short-term loans if they can't get credit through a traditional bank.

"Facebook and others are making a blanket assessment about the payday-lending industry rather than discerning the good actors from the bad actors," the Community Financial Services Association of America, a payday-lending trade group, said in a statement. "This is unfair towards those that are legal, licensed lenders."

Millions of low-income Americans use the short-term loans to get cash quickly while planning to repay their balance once they get their next paycheque. But all too often, borrowers get caught in a vicious cycle where fees quickly mount and annual interest rates can be in the triple-digits.

In many cases, this debt drama plays out online - and starts with a search query.

Google itself had previously taken some steps to limit payday loan ads. The decision to ban them outright came, in part, after pressure from a coalition of civil liberties, consumer protection, and privacy groups that reached out to the search giant about the issue late last year.

To enforce the policy, those seeking to market financial products through Google's sprawling advertising network will be required to disclose the length of the loan and the annual interest rate before they will be allowed to place ads. The same standards will apply to sites that serve as middlemen who connect distressed borrowers to those lenders.

Google, of course, has also profited from those ads. Although they likely make up only a small fraction of the company's staggering online advertising revenues - which were more than $18 billion (U.S.) in the first quarter of this year - banning them will mean the company is leaving dollars on the table.

urn:contentItem:5JRV-JYB1-DY19-C03M-00000-00Google to ban payday loan advertisements2016-05-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:27ZLexisNexisGoogle to ban payday loan advertisementsAndrea Peterson and Jonnelle Marte

Google has announced it will ban all payday loan ads from its site, bowing to concerns by critics who say the lending practice exploits the poor and vulnerable by offering them immediate cash that must be paid back under sky-high interest rates.

The decision is the first time Google has announced a global ban on ads for a broad category of financial products. To this point, the search giant has prohibited ads for largely illicit activities such as selling guns, explosives and drugs, and limited those that are sexually explicit or graphic in nature, for example. Critics of payday lenders say they hope the move by Google and other tech companies might undercut the business which finds huge numbers of willing customers on the internet.

The move also shows the willingness of big tech companies to weigh in on critical policy issues -- and exert their power as the gateways for the internet. Facebook also does not display ads for payday loans. But others, such as Yahoo, still do.

Consumers will still be able to find payday lenders from a Google search. But the ads that appear on the top and right-hand side of a search results page will not show marketing from the payday lending industry beginning on July 13.

"We'll continue to review the effectiveness of this policy, but our hope is that fewer people will be exposed to misleading or harmful products," Google global product policy director David Graff said in a blog post about the change.

In Australia, the payday industry and online lenders using algorithms to assess consumer creditworthiness have come into the spotlight following action by the corporate watchdog against payday lender Nimble, which had been forced to refund $1.6 million to more than 7000 customers after it was found to engage in irresponsible lending.

In the US, regulators and a handful of states have been trying to limit the activities of payday lenders by capping how much they can charge consumers in an interest rate. But the decisions by tech giants Facebook and Google - the two biggest websites on the planet - might have as much impact as any single regulation in restricting access to payday lenders.

Industry officials, speaking generally of advertising restrictions placed on payday lenders, called the policies "discriminatory," adding that some consumers may need access to the short-term loans if they can't get credit through a traditional bank.

"Facebook and others are making a blanket assessment about the payday lending industry rather than discerning the good actors from the bad actors," the Community Financial Services Association of America, a payday lending trade group, said in a statement. "This is unfair towards those that are legal, licensed lenders."

Millions of low-income earners use the short-term loans to get cash quickly while planning to repay their balance once they get their next paycheck. But all too often, borrowers get caught in a vicious cycle where fees quickly mount and annual interest rates can be in the triple-digits.

Debt drama

In many cases, this debt drama plays out online -- and starts with a search query.

"You search the internet when you need help -- and as a result you may give search engines some really sensitive information about your finances," explained Alvaro Bedoya, the executive director of Georgetown Law's Center on Privacy & Technology. When those desperate searches return targeted ads for payday loans, lenders end up profiting from the weaknesses those people have shared, he said.

But once a borrower has committed to an online payday loan, they may end up facing unexpected financial risks. According to a recent US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau analysis, half of borrowers who took out online payday loans were later hit with an average of $US185 ($252) worth of bank fees or penalties when a lender submitted automatic repayment requests they couldn't afford.

The CFPB is working on a proposed rule targeting the industry which it expects to unveil later this spring. The agency is considering rules that would limit the number of times consumers could roll over a loan, capping them at two or three loans total. The rules might also require lenders to verify consumers' income and borrowing history to gauge their ability to pay back the loan.

Google itself had previously taken some steps to limit payday loan ads. The decision to ban them outright came in part after pressure from a coalition of civil liberties, consumer protection, and privacy groups that reached out to the search giant about the issue late last year.

Longstanding concerns

The Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights was one of those groups. "This new policy addresses many of the longstanding concerns shared by the entire civil rights community about predatory payday lending," Wade Henderson, the group's president and chief executive, said in a statement. "Low-income people and people of colour have long been targeted by slick advertising and aggressive marketing campaigns to trap consumers into outrageously high interest loans."

To enforce the policy, those seeking to market financial products through Google's sprawling advertising network will be required to disclose the length of the loan and the annual interest rate before they will be allowed to place ads. In addition to the broad payday loan ad ban, Google will not display ads from lenders who charge annual interest rates of 36 per cent or more in the United States. The same standards will apply to sites that serve as middlemen who connect distressed borrowers to those lenders.

That's important because banning ads for payday loans themselves may not be enough, according to some advocates. "If you type in a search term that indicates financial distress, most of the ads you'll see will be for websites that are not the payday lenders themselves, but marketing companies who collect leads then auction them off to the lenders," said Aaron Rieke, one of the authors of a report on online payday lending advertisements released by consulting firm Upturn last year.

Google, of course, has also profited from those ads. Although they likely make up only a small fraction of the company's staggering online advertising revenues -- which were more than $US18 billion in the first quarter of this year -- banning them will mean the company is leaving dollars on the table.

To advocates like Bedoya, that's a good thing.

"Google is taking a principled stance here," he said. "Hopefully, it's one that will help set a new standard for search engines."

The Washington Post

urn:contentItem:5JRW-SCY1-JCBK-1542-00000-00Google to ban payday loan advertisements2016-05-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisA SECTIONAPg. 15Googleto ban payday loan advertisementsAndrea Peterson and Jonnelle Marte, The Washington Post

PHOTO: U.S. regulators and some states have been trying to limit payday lenders' activities.Gary Tramontina/Bloomberg News

Googleto ban payday loan advertisements

Aims to expose fewer users to 'harmful products'

By Andrea Peterson and Jonnelle Marte

The Washington Post

Googleannounced Wednesday that it will ban all payday loan ads from its site, bowing to concerns by advocates who say the lending practice exploits the poor and vulnerable by offering them immediate cash that must be paid back under sky-high interest rates.

The decision is the first time Googlehas announced a global ban on ads for a broad category of financial products. Critics of payday lenders say they hope the move by Googleand other tech companies might undercut the business, which finds huge numbers of willing customers on the Internet.

The move also shows the willingness of big tech companies to weigh in on critical policy issues. Facebook also does not display ads for payday loans. But others, such as Yahoo, still do.

Consumers will still be able to find payday lenders from a Googlesearch. But the ads that appear on the top and right-hand side of a search results page will not show marketing from the payday lending industry beginning July 13.

"We'll continue to review the effectiveness of this policy, but our hope is that fewer people will be exposed to misleading or harmful products," Googleglobal product policy director David Graff said in a blog post about the change.

Washington regulators, as well as a handful of states, have been trying to limit the activities of payday lenders by capping how much they can charge consumers in an interest rate.

Industry officials, speaking generally of advertising restrictions placed on payday lenders, called the policies "discriminatory," adding that some consumers may need access to the short-term loans if they can't get credit through a traditional bank.

"Facebook and others are making a blanket assessment about the payday lending industry rather than discerning the good actors from the bad actors," the Community Financial Services Association of America, a payday lending trade group, said in a statement. "This is unfair towards those that are legal, licensed lenders."

Millions of low-income Americans use the short-term loans to get cash quickly while planning to repay their balance once they get their next paycheck. But all too often, borrowers get caught in a vicious cycle where fees quickly mount and annual interest rates can be in the triple-digits.

According to a Consumer Financial Protection Bureau analysis, half of borrowers who took out online payday loans were hit with an average of $185 worth of bank fees or penalties when a lender submitted automatic repayment requests they couldn't afford.

Those seeking to market financial products through Google's advertising network will be required to disclose the length of the loan and the annual interest rate before they will be allowed to place ads. In addition to the broad payday loan ad ban, Googlewill not display ads from lenders who charge annual interest rates of 36 percent or more in the United States.

urn:contentItem:5JRR-4CD1-DXKP-J017-00000-00Google to ban payday loan advertisements2016-05-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:26ZLexisNexisGoogle to ban payday loan advertisementsAndrea Peterson;Jonnelle Marte

Google announced Wednesday that it will ban all payday loan ads from its site, bowing to concerns by advocates who say the lending practice exploits the poor and vulnerable by offering them immediate cash that must be paid back under sky-high interest rates.

The decision is the first time Google has announced a global ban on ads for a broad category of financial products. To this point, the search giant has prohibited ads for largely illicit activities such as selling guns, explosives and drugs, and limited those that are sexually explicit or graphic in nature, for example. Critics of payday lenders say they hope the move by Google and other tech companies might undercut the business which finds huge numbers of willing customers on the internet.

The move also shows the willingness of big tech companies to weigh in on critical policy issues -- and exert their power as the gateways for the internet. Facebook also does not display ads for payday loans. But others, such as Yahoo, still do.

Consumers will still be able to find payday lenders from a Google search. But the ads that appear on the top and right-hand side of a search results page will not show marketing from the payday lending industry beginning on July 13.

"We'll continue to review the effectiveness of this policy, but our hope is that fewer people will be exposed to misleading or harmful products," Google global product policy director David Graff said in a blog post about the change.

Washington regulators, as well as a handful of states, have been trying to limit the activities of payday lenders by capping how much they can charge consumers in an interest rate. But the decisions by tech giants Facebook and Google - the two biggest websites on the planet - might have as much impact as any single regulation in restricting access to payday lenders.

Industry officials, speaking generally of advertising restrictions placed on payday lenders, called the policies "discriminatory," adding that some consumers may need access to the short-term loans if they can't get credit them through a traditional bank.

"Facebook and others are making a blanket assessment about the payday lending industry rather than discerning the good actors from the bad actors," the Community Financial Services Association of America, a payday lending trade group, said in a statement. "This is unfair towards those that are legal, licensed lenders."

Millions of low-income Americans use the short-term loans to get cash quickly while planning to repay their balance once they get their next paycheck. But all too often, borrowers get caught in a vicious cycle where fees quickly mount and annual interest rates can be in the triple-digits.

In many cases, this debt drama plays out online -- and starts with a search query.

"You search the internet when you need help -- and as a result you may give search engines some really sensitive information about your finances," explained Alvaro Bedoya, the executive director of Georgetown Law's Center on Privacy & Technology. When those desperate searches return targeted ads for payday loans, lenders end up profiting from the weaknesses those people have shared, he said.

But once a borrower has committed to an online payday loan, they may end up facing unexpected financial risks. According to a recent Consumer Financial Protection Bureau analysis, half of borrowers who took out online payday loans were later hit with an average of $185 worth of bank fees or penalties when a lender submitted automatic repayment requests they couldn't afford.

And payday loans taken out online can also be more expensive than those borrowed from storefronts. For example, borrowers taking out the average payday loan of $375 would pay a $95 fee online compared with $55 at a store, according to Pew Charitable Trust.

While the total amount of payday loans taken out each year has declined slightly in recent years, online payday lenders are making up a bigger share of the market. About 40 percent of the roughly $40 billion issued in payday loans in 2015 were taken out online, according to estimates from Jefferies.

The move could make it more difficult, though not impossible, for online payday lenders to find new customers, said John Hecht, an analyst at Jefferies.

"Certainly when Google modifies or limits advertising or search results it can have a definite impact on an industry right away," Hecht said. But consumers who want a payday loan would still be able to turn to other search engines or they could visit a storefront, he added.

The CFPB is working on a proposed rule targeting the industry which it expects to unveil later this spring. The agency is considering rules that would limit the number of times consumers could rollover a loan, capping them at two or three loans total. The rules might also require lenders to verify consumers' income and borrowing history to gauge their ability to pay back the loan.

Google itself had previously taken some steps to limit payday loan ads. The decision to ban them outright came in part after pressure from a coalition of civil liberties, consumer protection, and privacy groups that reached out to the search giant about the issue late last year.

The Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights was one of those groups. "This new policy addresses many of the longstanding concerns shared by the entire civil rights community about predatory payday lending," Wade Henderson, the group's president and chief executive, said in a statement. "Low-income people and people of color have long been targeted by slick advertising and aggressive marketing campaigns to trap consumers into outrageously high interest loans."

To enforce the policy, those seeking to market financial products through Google's sprawling advertising network will be required to disclose the length of the loan and the annual interest rate before they will be allowed to place ads. In addition to the broad payday loan ad ban, Google will not display ads from lenders who charge annual interest rates of 36 percent or more in the United States. The same standards will apply to sites that serve as middlemen who connect distressed borrowers to those lenders.

That's important because banning ads for payday loans themselves may not be enough, according to some advocates. "If you type in a search term that indicates financial distress, most of the ads you'll see will be for websites that are not the payday lenders themselves, but marketing companies who collect leads then auction them off to the lenders," said Aaron Rieke, one of the authors of a report on online payday lending advertisements released by consulting firm Upturn last year.

Google, of course, has also profited from those ads. Although they likely make up only a small fraction of the company's staggering online advertising revenues -- which were more than $18 billion in the first quarter of this year -- banning them will mean the company is leaving dollars on the table.

To advocates like Bedoya, that's a good thing.

"Google is taking a principled stance here," he said. "Hopefully, it's one that will help set a new standard for search engines."

The same standards will apply to sites that serve as middlemen who connect distressed borrowers to those lenders.

That's important because banning ads for payday loans themselves may not be enough, according to some advocates. "If you type in a search term that indicates financial distress, most of the ads you'll see will be for websites that are not the payday lenders themselves, but marketing companies who collect leads then auction them off to the lenders," said Aaron Rieke, one of the authors of a report on online payday lending advertisements released by consulting firm Upturn last year.

Google, of course, has also profited from those ads. Although they likely make up only a small fraction of the company's staggering online advertising revenues -- which were more than $US18 billion in the first quarter of this year -- banning them will mean the company is leaving dollars on the table.

To advocates like Bedoya, that's a good thing.

"Google is taking a principled stance here," he said. "Hopefully, it's one that will help set a new standard for search engines."

The Washington Post

urn:contentItem:5JRW-GMJ1-DXY8-V00J-00000-00Google to ban payday loan advertising;Aims to expose fewer users to 'harmful products'2016-05-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:56:27ZLexisNexis BUSINESS ZONE CPg. 1Google to ban payday loan advertisingAims to expose fewer users to 'harmful products'By Andrea Peterson and Jonnelle Marte, The Washington Post

Google announced Wednesday that it will ban all payday loan ads from its site, bowing to concerns by advocates who say the lending practice exploits the poor and vulnerable by offering them immediate cash that must be paid back under sky-high interest rates.

The decision is the first time Google has announced a global ban on ads for a broad category of financial products. To this point, the search giant has prohibited ads for largely illicit activities such as selling guns, explosives and drugs, and limited those that are sexually explicit or graphic in nature, for example.

Critics of payday lenders say they hope the move by Google and other tech companies might undercut the business, which finds huge numbers of willing customers on the Internet.

The move also shows the willingness of big tech companies to weigh in on critical policy issues. Facebook also does not display ads for payday loans. But others, such as Yahoo, still do.

Consumers will still be able to find payday lenders from a Google search. But the ads that appear on the top and right-hand side of a search results page will not show marketing from the payday lending industry beginning July 13.

"We'll continue to review the effectiveness of this policy, but our hope is that fewer people will be exposed to misleading or harmful products," Google global product policy director David Graff said in a blog post about the change.

Washington regulators, as well as a handful of states, have been trying to limit the activities of payday lenders by capping how much they can charge consumers in an interest rate.

Industry officials, speaking generally of advertising restrictions placed on payday lenders, called the policies "discriminatory," adding that some consumers may need access to the short-term loans if they can't get credit through a traditional bank.

"Facebook and others are making a blanket assessment about the payday lending industry rather than discerning the good actors from the bad actors," the Community Financial Services Association of America, a payday lending trade group, said in a statement. "This is unfair towards those that are legal, licensed lenders."

Millions of low-income Americans use the short-term loans to get cash quickly while planning to repay their balance once they get their next paycheck. But all too often, borrowers get caught in a vicious cycle where fees quickly mount and annual interest rates can be in the triple-digits.

According to a Consumer Financial Protection Bureau analysis, half of borrowers who took out online payday loans were hit with an average of $185 worth of bank fees or penalties when a lender submitted automatic repayment requests they couldn't afford.

Those seeking to market financial products through Google's advertising network will be required to disclose the length of the loan and the annual interest rate before they will be allowed to place ads. In addition to the broad payday loan ad ban, Google will not display ads from lenders who charge annual interest rates of 36 percent or more in the United States.
